         <tei:p>Pseudochirella tuberculata Tanaka, 1957</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 4 females and I male taken in 4 RMT i hauls made at<tei:lb/>1250-700 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 12 and 17 November 1969.<tei:lb/>The male is deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 525.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>3 o8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 7. Pseudochirella tuberculata &lt;J. a, body, dorsal ; b, and antenna ; c, mandible ;<tei:lb/>d, ist maxilla ; e, 2nd maxilla ; f, maxilliped ; g, ist leg ; h, 2nd leg ; i, 4th leg ; j, 5th<tei:lb/>leg ; k, 5th leg, left exopodite ; 1, 5th leg, right 3rd exopodite segment. Bar scale o-i mm<tei:lb/>unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 7) : Body length 576 mm. The cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>robust and oval ; it is 3-1 times as long as the 5-segmented abdomen. The head<tei:lb/>and ist thoracic segment are fused. Thoracic segments 4 and 5 are separate ; the<tei:lb/>5th segment is rounded laterally and has no spines. The rostrum is a single spike<tei:lb/>directed ventrally. The ist antenna has 21 segments and reaches to the hind edge<tei:lb/>of the 3rd abdominal segment. The remaining mouthparts are as shown. The</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 309</tei:p>
         <tei:p>exopodite of the and antenna is 1-4 times as long as the endopodite. The ist and<tei:lb/>2nd maxillae and the mandible blade are reduced. The exopodite of the ist leg<tei:lb/>has three segments and the endopodite has a comb of spines. The endopodite of<tei:lb/>the 2nd leg has only one segment but with an evident line of fusion ; the 3rd and<tei:lb/>4th legs have 3-segmented endopodites. The 5th pair of legs is as shown : on the<tei:lb/>left side (Fig. 7k) the 2nd exopodite segment has two strong points, and the 3rd<tei:lb/>segment is kidney-shaped with bunches of hairs ; the 3rd segment of the right<tei:lb/>exopodite (Fig. 7!) has two lamellae - one on a central swelling and one terminating<tei:lb/>the segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This specimen does not fit the description of any known male Pseudo-<tei:lb/>chirella. It is nearest to Tanaka &amp; Omori's (1969) account of P. polyspina Brodsky,<tei:lb/>1950, but it is larger and differs in the detail of the mouthparts and 5th pair of<tei:lb/>legs - especially the right exopodite. It was found in association with females of<tei:lb/>P. tuberculata and P. obtusa (Sars, 1905). It does not agree with the description<tei:lb/>of the male P. obtusa given by Vervoort (1949). Apart from sexual characters, it<tei:lb/>differs from Tanaka's (1957) account of the female P. tuberculata only in the ist leg,<tei:lb/>where his specimen had only two exopodite segments and had no comb of spines on<tei:lb/>the endopodite. The present females, however, show some variation in the degree<tei:lb/>of fusion of these exopodite segments and they do have a comb of spines. Specific<tei:lb/>attribution of Pseudochirella males is difficult but because the structures common to<tei:lb/>both sexes are so similar I believe that this specimen is the hitherto unknown male of<tei:lb/>P. tuberculata. This is the first Atlantic record of this species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Valdiviella minor Wolfenden, 1911</tei:p>
         <tei:p>? Valdiviella brevicornis ; Scott, 1909 : 78, pi. 22 ; Brodsky, 1950 : 223, fig. 137 (male only).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 2 females and i male from 2 RMT i hauls made at<tei:lb/>1250-1000 m depth in a position i8N 25W on 17 and 18 November 1969. The<tei:lb/>male is deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 526.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 8) : Body length 4-96 mm. The cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>3 times as long as the 5-segmented abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment<tei:lb/>are completely fused ; thoracic segments 4 and 5 are partially so. The head has<tei:lb/>prominent shoulders and the rostrum has two short spikes. The hind margin of<tei:lb/>the cephalothorax is rounded laterally and has no spines. The ist antennae are<tei:lb/>both broken off. The remaining mouthparts are identical to those described by<tei:lb/>Sewell (1929) for the male V. insignis. The legs are as shown. The ist leg has<tei:lb/>three exopodite segments but the 2nd, 3rd and 4th legs have only two. The 2nd<tei:lb/>leg has a single endopodite segment and legs 3 and 4 have two endopodite segments.<tei:lb/>The exopodites and endopodites of legs 2-4 all show signs of fusion between seg-<tei:lb/>ments. The 5th pair of legs is typical of the genus. The basipodite segments are<tei:lb/>much longer on the left side than on the right, but conversely the left endopod is<tei:lb/>much shorter than the right. The ist and 2nd exopodite segments of the left leg<tei:lb/>each have a small spine. The ist and 2nd exopodite segments of the right leg are<tei:lb/>partially fused and are drawn out into a long curved point.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 8. Valdiviella minor &lt;$. a, body, dorsal ; b, forehead and rostrum, lateral ; c, 2nd<tei:lb/>antenna ; d, mandibular palp ; e, ist maxilla ; f, 2nd maxilla ; g, maxilliped ; h, ist<tei:lb/>leg ; i, 2nd leg, j, 3rd leg ; k, 4th leg ; 1, 5th leg. Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This male was found with two undoubted females of V. minor. Both<tei:lb/>the females have the very characteristic chitinous ridge on the dorsal side of the<tei:lb/>genital segment and are identical to the descriptions of Wolfenden (1911) and Sewell<tei:lb/>(1929). They both measure 5-44 mm and are thus slightly larger than previous<tei:lb/>records. The present male is distinguished both in structure and size from males of<tei:lb/>V. insignis, V. oligarthra and V ' . ignota. Of the three smaller species, V. imperfecta<tei:lb/>is very poorly known, but females of V. brevicornis and V. minor can be identified</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 311</tei:p>
         <tei:p>easily. Scott (1909) described a male which he doubtfully attributed to V. brevi-<tei:lb/>cornis. Sewell (1929) also described a male as V. brevicornis and noted slight<tei:lb/>differences between his specimen and Scott's. Vervoort (1957) stated that Sewell's<tei:lb/>specimen (s) were 'undoubted males of V. brevicornis'. The present male is very<tei:lb/>similar to that described by Scott. As far as can be seen from his description it<tei:lb/>differs only in having the 4th and 5th thoracic segments and the ist and 2nd exo-<tei:lb/>podite segments of the right 5th leg partially fused instead of completely so. Sewell's<tei:lb/>specimen had a short spine on the posterior thoracic margin and a 3-segmented<tei:lb/>exopodite in the 2nd leg. I believe that Scott's male and the present specimen are<tei:lb/>conspecific. If the differences between them and Sewell's specimen of V. brevicornis<tei:lb/>are of specific value they may well be the hitherto undescribed male of V. minor,<tei:lb/>especially in view of the present association with females of this species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family PHAENNIDAE<tei:lb/>Xanthocalanus agilis Giesbrecht, 1892</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : i male taken in an RMT i haul made at 200-110 m depth<tei:lb/>in a position i8N 25W on 16 November 1969. Deposited at the British Museum<tei:lb/>(Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 527.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The present male (Fig. ga-d) measures 2-58 mm and agrees with<tei:lb/>Giesbrecht's (1892) description except for the 5th pair of legs. Giesbrecht described<tei:lb/>only the elongate left leg but it is not clear from his account whether the absence of<tei:lb/>the right leg was accidental or not. Giesbrecht &amp; Schmeil (1898) said that the right<tei:lb/>leg is absent. Other than restatements of Giesbrecht's original account I know of<tei:lb/>no other description of the male X. agilis. The general appearance of the present<tei:lb/>male is so similar to that of the female X. agilis that there can be no doubt that they<tei:lb/>are conspecific. The right leg of the 5th pair has five segments and is very short,<tei:lb/>reaching only to the end of the ist segment of the left leg. I believe that Giesbrecht's<tei:lb/>description is incomplete and that the male X. agilis has a pair of 5th legs in common<tei:lb/>with other males of this genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family SCOLECITHRICIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several authors have commented on the difficulties in classifying species within<tei:lb/>this large and complex family. Most recently, Bradford (1973) partially reviewed<tei:lb/>both the Phaennidae and the Scolecithricidae, redefining both families and some of<tei:lb/>their genera. Within the Scolecithricidae she found apparently consistent differ-<tei:lb/>ences in the setation of the ist maxilla of various genera, although the number of<tei:lb/>species which she examined was rather small. She was, however, unable to place<tei:lb/>definitely a large number of species into her redefined genera, either because of their<tei:lb/>structure or, presumably, because their descriptions are inadequate and many of<tei:lb/>their males unknown. It is therefore impossible, at the moment, to verify her<tei:lb/>narrower generic definitions for many species in this family. Re-examination of<tei:lb/>more species will clarify the acceptable limits for each genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>17</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>312</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 9. a-d, Xanthocalanus agilis &lt;?. a, body, dorsal ; b, last thoracic segment and<tei:lb/>abdomen, lateral ; c, 5th leg ; d, 5th leg, terminal segment left leg. e-g, Scottocalanus<tei:lb/>thomasi ?. e, body, dorsal ; f , forehead and rostrum, lateral ; g, genital segment,<tei:lb/>half lateral, h-r, Scaphocalanus sp. $. h, body, dorsal ; i, and antenna ; j, mandibular<tei:lb/>palp ; k, ist maxilla ; 1, 2nd maxilla ; m, maxilliped ; n, ist leg ; o, 2nd leg ; p, 4th leg,<tei:lb/>basipodite segments ; q, 5th leg ; r, 5th leg, 3rd exopodite segment left leg. s, Scolecithri-<tei:lb/>cella laminata ?, 2nd maxilla endopod. t-v, Scolecithricella laminata &lt;$. t, body, dorsal ;<tei:lb/>u, 5th leg ; v, 5th leg, 3rd exopodite segment left leg. Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 313</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The present collections contain several rare and new scolecithricid species.<tei:lb/>Some of these agree well with Bradford's generic definitions but some do not. A new<tei:lb/>genus is described for some of the latter species but others are maintained within<tei:lb/>existing genera pending further study of the variation within these.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scottocalanus thomasi Scott, 1909</tei:p>
         <tei:p>? Scottocalanus backusi Grice, 1969 : 451, figs 16-34.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 3 females and i male taken in 3 RMT i hauls made at<tei:lb/>500-210 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 12 and 16 November 1969.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The present females (Fig. ge-g) agree with Grice's (1969) description<tei:lb/>of 5. backusi which is, in turn, very similar to 5. thomasi. The females of these<tei:lb/>two species apparently differ only in the structure of their genital segment where<tei:lb/>S. backusi has a pair of spine-like protrusions. Sewell (1929), however, described<tei:lb/>the genital segment of 5. thomasi as having 'a finger-like backwardly directed<tei:lb/>projection near the posterior margin a little to the left of the middle line'. Scott<tei:lb/>(1909) made no mention of this. (Sewell's description of three endopodite segments<tei:lb/>on the ist maxilla of S. thomasi may be atypical since Scott described this as being<tei:lb/>'nearly similar' to that of S. securifrons which has only two endopodite segments.)<tei:lb/>I have examined a female specimen of 5. thomasi in the collections of the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History), which was taken at 'Investigator' Station 670 and<tei:lb/>presumably identified by Sewell. It has two spine-like projections on its genital<tei:lb/>segment exactly as shown here (Fig. 96, g). These projections are not always<tei:lb/>conspicuous, especially if they are bent back alongside the genital segment, and they<tei:lb/>can be easily overlooked, as they apparently were on this specimen. For this<tei:lb/>reason I think it probable that 5. backusi and 5. thomasi are conspecific. The<tei:lb/>present female specimens measure 5-92-6-08 mm and the male 5-92 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lophothrix latipes (T. Scott, 1894)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 5 females and 12 males taken in 7 Nii3H hauls made<tei:lb/>at 800-90 m depth off Fuerteventura (28N I4W), between 13 and 28 November<tei:lb/>1965. 13 females and 28 males taken in 9 RMT i hauls made at 700-49 m depth<tei:lb/>in a position i8N 25W, between 13 and 16 November 1969. 7 males are deposited<tei:lb/>at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 528-535.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 10) : Body length 2-96-3-19 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>3-05 mm (26 specimens). The cephalothorax is 3-4 times as long as the 5-segmented<tei:lb/>abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment are fused ; thoracic segments 4 and 5<tei:lb/>are separate. The head has a low crest and the forehead is angular in lateral view.<tei:lb/>The rostrum has two thick filaments. The head has prominent shoulders. The<tei:lb/>hind margin of the ist thoracic segment is undulating and the ventro-lateral margin<tei:lb/>of the 5th thoracic segment is abruptly cut off. The ist antenna has 20 segments<tei:lb/>and reaches to the end of the cephalothorax. The remaining mouthparts are as<tei:lb/>shown. The mandible blade, ist and 2nd maxillae and the maxilliped are reduced.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 10. Lophothrix latipes (?. a, body, dorsal ; b, forehead and rostrum, lateral ; c,<tei:lb/>thoracic segments 4 and 5, lateral ; d, 2nd antenna ; e, mandibular palp ; f, ist maxilla ;<tei:lb/>g, 2nd maxilla ; h, maxilliped ; i, ist leg ; j, 2nd leg ; k, 3rd leg ; 1, 4th leg ; m, 5th leg ;<tei:lb/>n, 5th leg, last exopodite segment right leg ; o, 5th leg, terminal exopodite segments<tei:lb/>left leg ; p, 5th leg, last endopodite segment left leg. Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 315</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The endopod of the 2nd maxilla has six sensory setae, none of which are brush-like.<tei:lb/>The first four pairs of legs are identical to those of the female. The 5th pair of legs<tei:lb/>are asymmetric and reach back to the hind edge of the 3rd abdominal segment.<tei:lb/>In the right leg, the exopodite has four segments, the last of which is flattened and<tei:lb/>roughly triangular in shape ; the endopodite is short and has two segments. The<tei:lb/>left leg has longer basipodite segments, the exopodite has three segments and the<tei:lb/>endopodite has two ; the last exopodite segment has two wide setae and numerous<tei:lb/>spines ; the endopodite terminates in a ribbon-like seta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Wilson (1950) described a male as L. latipes which differs in many<tei:lb/>respects from the present specimens, particularly in its mouthparts, which were<tei:lb/>described as 'like those of the female', and in its 5th pair of legs. There is some<tei:lb/>confusion between Wilson's description and his figures. His figure of the lateral<tei:lb/>view of the complete animal shows a distinct crest on the forehead, but he described<tei:lb/>this as 'evenly rounded with no trace of a crest'. The same figure shows a prominent<tei:lb/>spine on the posterior margin of the last thoracic segment ; this is described as<tei:lb/>'smoothly rounded' in the text. The present males are so similar to the females<tei:lb/>in all structures common to both sexes that I have no doubt that they are con-<tei:lb/>specific. The mouthparts are typically reduced but the cephalothorax, particularly<tei:lb/>the characteristic low crest and last thoracic segment, and the swimming legs, are<tei:lb/>identical to those of the female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scaphocalanus difficilis sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 64 females from 8 RMT i hauls made at 700-210 m depth<tei:lb/>in a position i8N 25W, between 12 and 17 November 1969. The holotype was<tei:lb/>caught between 600 and 515 m on 14 November 1969. Deposited at the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History), holotype reg. no. 1974 : 536, paratypes reg. no.<tei:lb/>1974 : 537-557-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. n) : Body length 1-29-1-44 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>1-38 mm (44 specimens). The holotype measures 1-37 mm. The cephalothorax<tei:lb/>is elongate and is 3-5 times as long as the 4-segmented abdomen. The head and<tei:lb/>ist thoracic segment are fused as are thoracic segments 4 and 5. The rostrum has<tei:lb/>two tapering filaments. The hind margin of the cephalothorax is flattened in<tei:lb/>lateral view. The abdominal segments and furcal rami have the following pro-<tei:lb/>portional lengths :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seg. 1 + 23 4 5 F. rami</tei:p>
         <tei:p>30 : 19 : 19 : 13 : 19 = 100</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The furcal rami are twice as long as wide. The ist antenna is broken in all<tei:lb/>specimens ; the near-basal segments are flattened and typical of the genus. In<tei:lb/>the 2nd antenna the endopodite is 1-4 times longer than the exopodite. In the<tei:lb/>ist maxilla the ist inner lobe has only two surface setae and the 3rd inner lobe has<tei:lb/>only three setae. The endopod of the 2nd maxilla has five brush-like setae, of<tei:lb/>which two are enlarged, and three flattened worm-like setae. The ist pair of legs<tei:lb/>has no external spine on either the ist or 2nd exopodite segments. The outer spine</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>n</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. ii. Scaphocalanus difficilis ?. a, body, dorsal; b, abdomen and last thoracic<tei:lb/>segment, lateral ; c, rostrum, lateral ; d, rostrum, ventral ; e, 2nd antenna ; f, ist<tei:lb/>maxilla ; g, 2nd maxilla ; h, maxilliped ; i, ist leg ; j, 2nd leg ; k, 3rd leg ; 1, 3rd leg,<tei:lb/>ist basipodite segment (paratype) ; m, 4th leg ; n, 5th leg. Bar scale o-i mm unless<tei:lb/>indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>on the ist exopodite segment of the 2nd leg is short. The basipodite segments of<tei:lb/>the 3rd and 4th legs have varying numbers of small surface spines. The 5th leg<tei:lb/>has a single segment on each side carrying two spines ; the inner spine is 1-8 times<tei:lb/>longer than the terminal one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The small size of the present species distinguishes it from all other<tei:lb/>Scaphocalanus species which have a well-developed 5th pair of legs. S. longifurca<tei:lb/>(Giesbrecht, 1888) is only slightly larger ($ 1-48-1-90 mm -limits from Tanaka,<tei:lb/>1961, and Grice &amp; Hulsemann, 1965). The present species differs from Giesbrecht's<tei:lb/>(1892) description of 5. longifurca in the following characters : (a) the endopod of the<tei:lb/>2nd antenna longer than the exopod, (b) a relatively shorter abdomen, (c) different<tei:lb/>proportional lengths of the abdominal segments, (d) no outer spine on the 2nd</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 317</tei:p>
         <tei:p>exopodite segment of the ist leg, (e) a more or less straight outer spine on the ist<tei:lb/>exopodite segment of the 2nd leg, and (f) different proportional lengths of the spines<tei:lb/>on the 5th leg. Giesbrecht (1892), Vervoort (1951) and Tanaka (1961) all described<tei:lb/>spines on the basal segments of legs 2-4 in 5. longifurca. Vervoort said that these<tei:lb/>form a 'dense covering' on the 3rd leg and according to Tanaka these same joints<tei:lb/>are 'coarsely covered'. Without illustrations it is difficult to decide on the degree of<tei:lb/>spinulation in these descriptions. The present specimens have a varying number of<tei:lb/>small spines on these basal segments but they are relatively few in number.<tei:lb/>Tanaka's (1961) specimens of S. longifurca have the endopod of the 2nd antenna<tei:lb/>longer than the exopod, and the cephalothorax is 3-5 times as long as the abdomen.<tei:lb/>They differ from the present females, however, in the proportional lengths of the<tei:lb/>abdominal segments and in the shape of the hind margin of the cephalothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5. siibbrevicornis (Wolfenden, 1911) is very similar, if not identical, with 5. longi-<tei:lb/>furca (Farran, 1929 ; Vervoort, 1951 ; Tanaka, 1961). In some of the slight differ-<tei:lb/>ences between these two species - the proportions of the rami of the 2nd antenna,<tei:lb/>the straight outer spine of the ist exopodite segment of the 2nd leg of 5. subbrevi-<tei:lb/>cornis, and the degree of spinulation of the basal joints of legs 2-4-5. subbrevicornis<tei:lb/>is structurally more similar to the present species. Moreover, the relative length of<tei:lb/>the abdomen and the proportional lengths of the abdominal segments are also<tei:lb/>similar to the present females (Tanaka, 1961). 5. subbrevicornis is, however,<tei:lb/>larger, females measuring 1-60-2-10 mm (extremes from Vervoort, 1957, and Grice<tei:lb/>&amp; Hulsemann, 1965) and there are differences in the ist and possibly also the 5th<tei:lb/>pair of legs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Whether or not these slight differences merit separation into three species is<tei:lb/>questionable. It may be necessary to amalgamate two or all of them in future<tei:lb/>but for the moment at least they can remain separate. The ist maxilla of 5.<tei:lb/>difficilis differs from Bradford's (1973) definition of the genus in having only two<tei:lb/>surface setae on the ist inner lobe and three setae on the 3rd inner lobe. This last<tei:lb/>character is shared with other scaphocalanids, however, e.g. 5. similis and S. invalidus<tei:lb/>(Hure &amp; Scotto di Carlo, 1968), and the general structure of the present species is so<tei:lb/>similar to Scaphocalanus that there can be no doubt that it belongs to this genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scaphocalanus sp.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 3 males taken in 2 RMT i hauls, one at 900-800 m depth<tei:lb/>and the other at 500-410 m, in a position i8N 25W on 14 and 16 November 1969.<tei:lb/>Deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 558-560.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. gh-r) : Body length 1-98-2-13 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>2-05 mm (3 specimens). The cephalothorax is 1-9 times as long as the 5-segmented<tei:lb/>abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment are completely fused, thoracic<tei:lb/>segments 4 and 5 are partially so. The rostrum has two thickened filaments. The<tei:lb/>abdominal segments and furcal rami have the following proportional lengths :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seg. i 2 3 4 5 F. rami</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13 : 26 : 21 : 29 : 3 : 8 = 100</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>318 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ist antenna has 20 segments and reaches back to the hind edge of the 2nd<tei:lb/>abdominal segment ; the first eight segments have long sensory setae. The re-<tei:lb/>maining mouthparts are as shown. The swimming legs are damaged in all specimens.<tei:lb/>The outer spine on the ist exopodite segment of the 2nd leg is moderately long and<tei:lb/>straight. The basipodite segments of legs 2-4 are covered with small surface spines<tei:lb/>which are particularly dense on legs 3 and 4. The 5th pair of legs reaches back to<tei:lb/>the end of the abdomen. On the left side the exopodite is much shorter than<tei:lb/>the endopodite ; the last exopodite segment has some coarse setae and a lamella,<tei:lb/>and the endopodite has no marked swelling along its length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. These specimens cannot be identified with any of the known Scapho-<tei:lb/>calanus males. The abdomen, with an unswollen 2nd segment, is similar to that<tei:lb/>described for 5. echinatus by Tanaka (1961) but the present males are larger and<tei:lb/>have a different 5th pair of legs. As the males of several Scaphocalanus species are<tei:lb/>unknown and as these specimens are all damaged they cannot be described as new<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithricella obscura sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 10 females taken in 3 RMT i hauls made at 1250-800 m<tei:lb/>depth and i female taken in an RMT i haul at 500-410 m. The holotype was<tei:lb/>taken at 1250-1000 m on 16 November 1969. All hauls were made in a position<tei:lb/>i8N 25W, between 14 and 18 November 1969. Deposited at the British Museum<tei:lb/>(Natural History), holotype reg. no. 1974 : 561, paratypes reg. no. 1974 : 562-570.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 12) : Body length 1-82 -2-13 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>2-04 mm (10 specimens). The holotype measures 1-90 mm. The cephalothorax<tei:lb/>is an elongated oval, and is 5-9 times as long as the 4-segmented abdomen. The<tei:lb/>head and ist thoracic segment and thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused. The<tei:lb/>rostrum has two thick filaments. The hind margin of the cephalothorax is indented<tei:lb/>laterally. The genital segment is as long as the combined length of the two sub-<tei:lb/>sequent segments. The furcal rami are about as long as wide. The ist antenna is<tei:lb/>broken in all specimens. The remaining mouthparts are as shown. The endopod<tei:lb/>of the 2nd maxilla has five brush-like setae, two of which are much larger than the<tei:lb/>others, and three flattened worm-like setae. In the maxilliped the ist basipodite<tei:lb/>is about two-thirds the length of the second, and carries one brush-like and two<tei:lb/>worm-like setae. The legs are as shown. There is no external spine on the ist<tei:lb/>exopodite segment of the ist leg. All the outer edge spines on the exopodite<tei:lb/>segments of the 2nd leg are long. The 5th pair of legs is uniramous and symmetrical.<tei:lb/>On each side there is a single segment, incompletely divided into three, having a<tei:lb/>small external spine - which is absent on one side of one of the paratypes, a longer<tei:lb/>terminal spine and a long stout internal spine garnished with teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species agrees generally with Scolecithricella as defined by<tei:lb/>Bradford (1973). It can be distinguished from all others in the genus by its 5th pair<tei:lb/>of legs, which are more like those found in Amallothrix and are very similar to those<tei:lb/>of ? Amallothrix valens (Farran, 1926). The great development of two of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>319</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 12. Bar scale<tei:lb/>o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>320 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>brush-like setae of the 2nd maxilla approaches the condition seen in Amallothrix<tei:lb/>alter a (p. 331). Few authors have figured these setae in detail in Scolecithricella<tei:lb/>but in some species two of the brush-like setae are shorter and thicker than the<tei:lb/>others, though not, apparently, to the extent seen here (for example, see Rose,<tei:lb/>1942).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithricella laminata (Farran, 1926)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithrix laminata Farran, 1926 : 265, pi. 8 ; Bradford, 1973 : 143, 145.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithricella laminata ; Grice &amp; Hulsemann, 1965 : 239, figs i4g-m, I5a-j ; 1967 : 16 ;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Park, 1960 : 476 ; Wheeler, 1970 : 8 ; Roe, 1972^ : 304, 310 ; 1972^ : 540.<tei:lb/>S. lamellifer Tanaka, 1962 : 78, fig. 146.<tei:lb/>? Amallothrix profunda Brodsky, 1950 : 263, fig. 172 ; Bradford, 1973 : 144.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 3 females and i male from an Nii3H haul made at<tei:lb/>960-800 m depth off Fuerteventura (28N I4W) on 25 November 1965. 15<tei:lb/>females and 3 males from 5 RMT i hauls made at 1250-700 m depth in a position<tei:lb/>i8N 25W, between 12 and 18 November 1969. 3 females and the males are<tei:lb/>deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 571-577-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 95) : Body length 1-82-2-28 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>1-94 mm (14 specimens). Redescription of these females is unnecessary as they<tei:lb/>generally agree with Farran's (1926) account but have the modifications described<tei:lb/>by Grice &amp; Hulsemann (1965) and Tanaka (1962). The structure of the ist and 2nd<tei:lb/>maxillae, however, seems in need of clarification. The ist maxilla has the following<tei:lb/>number of setae : 5 large and 2 small on the ist outer lobe, 8 on the exopod, 5 on the<tei:lb/>fused 2nd and 3rd endopodite segment, 2 on the ist endopodite segment, 6 on the<tei:lb/>2nd basipodite, 4 on the 3rd inner lobe, 2 on the 2nd inner lobe and 13 on the ist<tei:lb/>inner lobe - of which 4 are on the surface as opposed to the edge. The 2nd maxilla<tei:lb/>(Fig. 95) has 8 sensory setae on the endopodite of which only 2 are short and brush-<tei:lb/>like and 6 are long and worm-like.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male (Fig. 9t-v) : Body length 2-20-2-43 mm with a mean of 2-35 mm (3 speci-<tei:lb/>mens). The cephalothorax is 2-3 times as long as the 5-segmented abdomen.<tei:lb/>The head and ist thoracic segment and thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused. The<tei:lb/>rostrum has two stout filaments. The hind margin of the cephalothorax is smoothly<tei:lb/>rounded. The ist antenna has 19 segments and reaches to the end of the furcal<tei:lb/>rami. The remaining mouthparts are generally slightly smaller and more weakly<tei:lb/>chitinized than in the female ; their setation patterns are identical to those of the<tei:lb/>female except in the following respects. The basipodite of the mandibular palp<tei:lb/>has no setae ; in the ist maxilla the ist outer lobe has six large and two small setae,<tei:lb/>the exopodite has nine and the 2nd basipodite has five setae. The endopodite of the<tei:lb/>2nd maxilla is as in the female with six long filaments and two shorter brush-like<tei:lb/>setae. In all the specimens the 2nd and 3rd exopodite segments of legs 2-4 are<tei:lb/>missing but the remainder of the swimming legs are identical to those of the female.<tei:lb/>The 5th pair of legs are asymmetrical and resemble those of Scaphocalanus. In the<tei:lb/>right leg the exopodite has three segments, the last of which is roughly triangular<tei:lb/>in shape. In the left leg the exopodite is much shorter than the 2-segmented</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 321</tei:p>
         <tei:p>endopodite ; the 3rd exopodite segment has bunches of fine hairs and two large<tei:lb/>setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Apart from the normal sexual characters these males are so similar to<tei:lb/>the females that there is no doubt that they are the same species. Brodsky's (1950)<tei:lb/>description of A. profunda is incomplete but the structure of the 5th pair of legs,<tei:lb/>especially the short exopodite of the left leg, is very similar to that of the present<tei:lb/>specimens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In her review of the Scolecithricidae, Bradford (1973) could not place this species<tei:lb/>into a genus. She suggested that it may belong to Amallothrix or to an unnamed<tei:lb/>group typified by Scolecithrix auropecten Giesbrecht, 1892. The combination of<tei:lb/>six worm-like and two brush-like setae on the endopod of the 2nd maxilla would<tei:lb/>exclude this species from the Scolecithricidae as defined by Bradford. However,<tei:lb/>this definition of the 2nd maxilla would also exclude Parascaphocalanus Brodsky,<tei:lb/>1955 although Bradford admits this genus to the family. In other respects the<tei:lb/>present species is a typical scolecithricid. The combination of the 2nd maxilla,<tei:lb/>a Lophothrix-type ist maxilla with four surface setae on the ist inner lobe, well-<tei:lb/>defined rostral filaments, a spine on the ist exopodite segment of the ist leg, and,<tei:lb/>in the male, relatively unreduced mouthparts and a Scaphocalanus-type 5th pair of<tei:lb/>legs, excludes this species from those genera defined by Bradford and from those<tei:lb/>not described by her. As mentioned earlier (p. 311), she had difficulty in definitely<tei:lb/>assigning a large number of species to genera, and rather than create a new mono-<tei:lb/>typic genus for the present species it seems better to place it into Scolecithricella as<tei:lb/>defined by Sars (1902), until examination of more species clarifies the limits of any<tei:lb/>narrower generic definitions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithricella aspinosa sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 9 females taken in 2 RMT i hauls - one fished at<tei:lb/>1250-1000 m depth on 17 November 1969 and the other (containing the holotype)<tei:lb/>at i22O-iooom on 18 November 1969. Both hauls were made at i8N 25W.<tei:lb/>Deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), holotype reg. no. 1974 : 578,<tei:lb/>paratypes reg. no. 1974 : 579 -586.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 13) : Body length 3-19-3-65 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>3-36 mm (8 specimens). The holotype measures 3-19 mm. The cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>oval and robust, and is 3-6 times as long as the 4-segmented abdomen. The head<tei:lb/>and ist thoracic segment are completely fused, thoracic segments 4 and 5 are<tei:lb/>partially so. The forehead is rounded in lateral view ; the rostrum has two fila-<tei:lb/>ments with thick sausage-shaped bases. The hind edge of the cephalothorax<tei:lb/>is slightly indented. The genital segment is longer than the combined length of the<tei:lb/>three subsequent segments. The furcal rami are about as long as wide. The<tei:lb/>ist antenna has 23 segments and reaches to the end of the furcal rami. The<tei:lb/>remaining mouthparts are as shown. The exopod of the ist maxilla has a group<tei:lb/>of spines. The endopod of the 2nd maxilla has five brush-like setae and three<tei:lb/>worm-like setae. In the holotype the worm-like setae are very wrinkled but this may</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>322</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 13.          <tei:p>be an artifact of preservation as in one of the paratypes these setae are simple<tei:lb/>flattened filaments. The basal segment of the maxilliped has one brush-like and<tei:lb/>two worm-like setae. The legs are as shown. The ist leg has no outer spine on<tei:lb/>either the ist or 2nd exopodite segment. In the 2nd leg the external spine of the ist<tei:lb/>exopodite segment is short, and the 2nd endopodite segment has a raised lobe<tei:lb/>carrying four spines. The endopods of legs 2-4 all have long spines on their pos-<tei:lb/>terior surfaces ; their anterior surfaces generally have small spines but those on the<tei:lb/>4th leg are fairly large. The 5th leg is symmetrical and uniramous. On each side<tei:lb/>there are two segments with the second having a distinct line of fusion and carrying<tei:lb/>a short terminal spine and a very long internal spine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Scolecithricella aspinosa and the following species are distinct in<tei:lb/>having no external spines on the ist and 2nd exopodite segments of the ist leg.<tei:lb/>Discussion of the affinities of both these species follows the description of Scole-<tei:lb/>cithricella canariensis on p. 325.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithricella canariensis sp. nov.<tei:lb/>Scolecithricella sp. 3 Roe, 19720 : 304, 310 ; 19726 : 540.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 2 females from 2 Nii3H hauls made at 960-825 m depth<tei:lb/>off Fuerteventura (28N I4W) on 25 and 27 November 1965. 9 females from<tei:lb/>6 RMT i hauls made at 1220-610 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between<tei:lb/>12 and 18 November 1969. The holotype was taken at 790-700 m on 12 November<tei:lb/>1969. Deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), holotype reg. no.<tei:lb/>1974 : 587, paratypes reg. no. 1974 : 588-597.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 14) : Body length 3-12-3-42 mm with a mean<tei:lb/>of 3-30 mm (n specimens). The holotype measures 3-19 mm. The cephalothorax<tei:lb/>is elongate and 5-1 times as long as the 4-segmented abdomen. The head and ist<tei:lb/>thoracic segment are fused, as are thoracic segments 4 and 5. The forehead is<tei:lb/>somewhat angular in dorsal view. The rostrum has two fairly long filaments. The<tei:lb/>hind margin of the cephalothorax is indented laterally. The genital segment is<tei:lb/>a little longer than the subsequent segment ; the furcal rami are slightly longer than<tei:lb/>wide. The ist antenna has 23 segments, the last of which extends past the furcal<tei:lb/>rami. The remaining mouthparts are as shown. The endopod of the 2nd maxilla<tei:lb/>has three ribbon-like setae and four brush-like setae. The basal segment of the<tei:lb/>maxilliped has two worm-like and one brush-like seta. The legs are as shown.<tei:lb/>The ist leg has no external spine on either the ist or 2nd exopodite segment. The<tei:lb/>2nd leg has a short outer edge spine on the ist exopodite segment and a distinct<tei:lb/>raised lobe bearing six spines on the 2nd endopodite segment. The 5th pair of legs<tei:lb/>is symmetrical and uniramous. On each side there is a single segment, which bears<tei:lb/>traces of fusion, attached to a common basal segment. Each terminal segment has<tei:lb/>a short end spine and a longer robust internal spine armed with short teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Scolecithricella canariensis and S. aspinosa are closely related. Both<tei:lb/>have (a) no trace of an external spine on the ist and 2nd exopodite segments of the<tei:lb/>ist leg, (b) a Lophothrix-type ist maxilla, (c) uniformly small heads to the brush-like</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>324</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 14. Scolecithricella canariensis ?. a, body, dorsal ; b, forehead and rostrum, lateral ;<tei:lb/>c, last thoracic segment and abdomen, lateral ; d, 2nd antenna ; e, mandibular palp ;<tei:lb/>f, ist maxilla ; g, 2nd maxilla, exopod ; h, 2nd maxilla, endopod ; i, maxilliped ; j, ist<tei:lb/>leg ; k, 2nd leg ; 1, 3rd leg ; m, 4th leg ; n, 5th leg. Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 325</tei:p>
         <tei:p>setae of the 2nd maxilla (S. canariensis apparently only has four of these setae),<tei:lb/>(d) a similar-shaped maxilliped, and (e) a short external spine on the ist exopodite<tei:lb/>segment of the 2nd leg and, in the same limb, a raised lobe on the 2nd endopodite<tei:lb/>segment. The two species are clearly distinct, however, differing from each other<tei:lb/>in body shape, the detailed setation of the ist maxilla and the structure of the legs.<tei:lb/>They both show similarities with Scaphocalanus bogorovi Brodsky, 1955. The<tei:lb/>exopodite of the ist leg is identical (see Grice &amp; Hulsemann, 1965), and the maxil-<tei:lb/>liped and the endopod of the 2nd maxilla are also very similar. There are differences,<tei:lb/>however, in the structure of the ist maxilla and in the legs. 5. bogorovi seems at<tei:lb/>best a very peculiar Scaphocalanus and should probably be removed from this genus.<tei:lb/>As with 5. laminata (p. 321) it is impossible to place either of the two present<tei:lb/>species into any of the scolecithricid genera defined by Bradford (1973), or into any<tei:lb/>of the remaining genera in this family. Both have some affinity to Lophothrix<tei:lb/>but also show a general resemblance to Amallothrix. The peculiar structure of<tei:lb/>their ist leg, however, is constant in all the present specimens and it may be necessary<tei:lb/>to establish a new genus for these species and also perhaps for S. bogorovi. Pending<tei:lb/>the discovery of the males and determination of the acceptable limits within each<tei:lb/>genus both species are temporarily placed within Scolecithricella Sars, 1902.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amallothrix falcifer (Farran, 1926)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithrix falcifer Farran, 1926 : 262, pi. 8 ; Bradford, 1973 : 143.<tei:lb/>Scolecithricella sp. 2 Roe, 1972^ : 296, 304, 310 ; 1972^ : 540.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : n females and 2 males taken in 10 Nii3H hauls made at<tei:lb/>960-510 m depth off Fuerteventura (28N I4W), between 24 and 28 November<tei:lb/>1965. 10 females and 7 males taken in 7 RMT i hauls made at 1250-700 m depth<tei:lb/>in a position i8N 25W, between 12 and 17 November 1969. One female and<tei:lb/>5 males are deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no.<tei:lb/>1974 : 598-603.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. I5a-m) : Body length 1-82-2-20 mm with a mean<tei:lb/>of 2-00 mm (20 specimens). The cephalothorax is oval and robust ; it is 3-8 times<tei:lb/>as long as the 4-segmented abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment are fused,<tei:lb/>as are thoracic segments 4 and 5. The forehead is rounded, the two rostral filaments<tei:lb/>are thickened over most of their length. The hind margin of the cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>slightly indented. The genital segment is almost as long as the combined length of<tei:lb/>the three subsequent segments. The furcal rami are only slightly longer than<tei:lb/>wide. The ist antenna has 23 segments and reaches back to the anal segment.<tei:lb/>The maxilliped has a sensory seta in the middle of the ist basipodite. The re-<tei:lb/>maining mouthparts are as shown. The 2nd maxilla has five brush-like setae on the<tei:lb/>endopodite and at least two ribbon-like setae. The legs are as shown. The internal<tei:lb/>edge of the 2nd basipodite of the 2nd leg has a characteristic group of spines. The<tei:lb/>surfaces of legs 2 and 3 are heavily ornamented with spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male (Fig. I5n-r) : Body length 1-98-2-81 mm with a mean of 2-50 mm (9<tei:lb/>specimens). The cephalothorax is 3 times longer than the 5-segmented abdomen.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 327</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The head and ist thoracic segment and thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused. The<tei:lb/>anal segment is very short. The ist antenna has 19 segments and reaches back to<tei:lb/>the hind edge of the 3rd abdominal segment. The setation of the mouthparts is<tei:lb/>identical to that of the female except in the following respects. In the 2nd antenna<tei:lb/>the exopodite has three terminal setae and the ist endopodite segment has a bunch<tei:lb/>of hairs. The ist maxilla is slightly variable ; in one specimen the ist outer lobe<tei:lb/>has eight setae, in another the 3rd inner lobe has three, and in both the 2nd basi-<tei:lb/>podite has five and the ist endopodite has three setae. In the 2nd maxilla lobes<tei:lb/>2-5 each has an enlarged seta typical of other Amattothrix males and the endo-<tei:lb/>podite has five brush-like setae and three ribbon-like setae. Two of the brush-like<tei:lb/>setae are short and one of these is conspicuously larger than the others. The<tei:lb/>swimming legs are identical to those of the female. The 5th pair of legs reaches<tei:lb/>back to the end of the abdomen. On the right leg the endopod is a short single<tei:lb/>segment and the last exopodite segment is leaf-shaped. On the left leg the endopod<tei:lb/>ends in a flagellum and the 3rd exopodite segment has a row of setae and a lamella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A . falcifer is difficult to recognize from Farran's (1926) account and<tei:lb/>apart from Wilson's (1950) figure of the female 5th legs it has never been redescribed.<tei:lb/>I have compared the present material with the type specimen held in the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History). The ist maxilla of the type is not mounted and the<tei:lb/>endopodite of the 2nd maxilla is rather obscure - it does, however, have at least<tei:lb/>four brush-like setae and three ribbon-like setae. In all other respects the present<tei:lb/>females are identical to the type. The 2nd leg of Farran's specimen has the charac-<tei:lb/>teristic group of spines on the 2nd basipodite although this is neither described nor<tei:lb/>figured by him. Apart from sexual characters and the slightly variable setation of<tei:lb/>some of the mouthparts the males are identical to the females. They have the<tei:lb/>distinct group of spines on the 2nd basipodite of the 2nd leg. There are, apparently,<tei:lb/>two size groups in the males. Two specimens each measured 1-98 mm but the<tei:lb/>remaining seven were between 2-58 and 2-81 mm in length. There are no structural<tei:lb/>differences between the large and small specimens and both are considered to be<tei:lb/>conspecific. Scolecithricella denticulata Tanaka, 1962 has a similar group of spines<tei:lb/>on the basipodite of the 2nd leg but its 5th pair of legs differs from the present males.<tei:lb/>Bradford (1973) could not definitely place A. falcifer into Amallothrix following her<tei:lb/>revision of the Scolecithricidae. The present specimens are in complete agreement<tei:lb/>with her definition of this genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amallothrix sp.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 6 males from 5 RMT i hauls made at 1220-610 m depth<tei:lb/>in a position i8N 25W, between 12 and 18 November 1969. Deposited at the<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 604-609.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 16) : Body length 2-05-2-81 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>2-43 mm (5 specimens). The cephalothorax is 2-5 times as long as the 5-segmented<tei:lb/>abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment and thoracic segments 4 and 5 are<tei:lb/>fused. The rostrum has two stout filaments. The ist antenna has 19 segments and<tei:lb/>reaches to the hind edge of the 2nd abdominal segment. The remaining mouthparts</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>328</tei:p>

         <tei:p>FIG. 1 6. Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>are as shown. There is some slight variation in setation of the ist maxilla where<tei:lb/>one specimen has nine setae on the exopodite. The swimming legs are incomplete<tei:lb/>in all specimens. The 3rd exopodite segment of the ist leg has surface spines ;<tei:lb/>the ist exopodite segment of the 2nd leg has a long curved outer spine. The basi-<tei:lb/>podites of legs 2-4 are covered with surface spines. The 5th pair of legs reaches<tei:lb/>back about half the length of the abdomen. On the left side the exopodite is<tei:lb/>slightly longer than the endopodite and the last exopodite segment has a lamella<tei:lb/>and groups of coarse setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. I cannot definitely identify these specimens with any of the known<tei:lb/>males of Amallothrix. They show a general similarity to the male of Amallothrix</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 329</tei:p>
         <tei:p>propinqua, described by Tanaka (1962), but differ in the spinulation of the swimming<tei:lb/>legs and in the structure of the 5th pair of legs. They agree with Bradford's (1973)<tei:lb/>redefinition of Amallothrix, but as they may be the undescribed male of a known<tei:lb/>species they are not considered here to be a new species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amallothrix lobophora (Park, 1970)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithricella lobophora Park, 1970 : 511, figs 188-201.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : n females and 4 males taken in 8 RMT i hauls made at<tei:lb/>785-300 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 13 and 17 November 1969.<tei:lb/>2 females and the males are deposited at the British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>reg. no. 1974 : 610-615.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 17): Body length 1-44-1-67 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>1-56 mm (4 specimens). The cephalothorax is 2-8 times as long as the 5-segmented<tei:lb/>abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment and thoracic segments 4 and 5 are<tei:lb/>fused. The forehead is flattened anteriorly in dorsal view ; the rostrum has two<tei:lb/>large swollen filaments. The hind margin of the cephalothorax is bluntly triangular<tei:lb/>in lateral view. The anal segment is very short and is telescoped into the 4th<tei:lb/>abdominal segment. The ist antenna has 19 free segments and reaches to the hind<tei:lb/>end of the abdomen ; the proximal segments have large sensory filaments. The<tei:lb/>mandible blade is similar to that of the female but smaller. The 2nd maxilla has<tei:lb/>five exopodite lobes but two have been omitted in Fig. I7h for clarity ; the endo-<tei:lb/>podite has five brush-like setae, two of which have enlarged heads, and three worm-<tei:lb/>like setae. The other mouthparts and the legs are as shown. The external spine<tei:lb/>on the 2nd exopodite segment of the ist leg varies slightly in length ; in another<tei:lb/>specimen it is longer than shown here. The 5th pair of legs is biramous and reaches<tei:lb/>back to the end of the abdomen. It is similar to that found in Scaphocalanus with<tei:lb/>the left endopodite longer than the exopodite. The left exopodite terminates in a<tei:lb/>lamella, which is broken in the illustrated specimen, and the last endopodite segment<tei:lb/>is knobbled. In the right leg the last exopodite segment is roughly triangular in<tei:lb/>shape.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. These males were taken in the same hauls as several female A.<tei:lb/>lobophora. The present females agree with Park's (1970) description except that the<tei:lb/>ist inner lobe of the ist maxilla has three surface setae and not two. Some of the<tei:lb/>male mouthparts are reduced but the characteristic rostrum and the swimming legs<tei:lb/>are identical to those of the female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bradford (1973) transferred this species from Scolecithricella Sars, 1902 to Amallo-<tei:lb/>thrix Sars, 1925. The present specimens differ from her redefinition of Amallothrix<tei:lb/>in having a Scaphocalanus-type. ist maxilla with three surface setae on the ist inner<tei:lb/>lobe. The 5th legs of both sexes also seem to be atypical of this genus and are very<tei:lb/>similar to those of Amallothrix auropecten (Giesbrecht, 1892). A discussion of the<tei:lb/>possible affinities of these two species is given after the account of A. auropecten<tei:lb/>on p. 334.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Amallothrix alter a (Farran, 1929)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>not Amallophora altera ; Vervoort, 1957 : 94~95&gt; fig s 77~79 ', Bradford, 1973 : 134, 136, 141,<tei:lb/>144-5, figs 2-3.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 331</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : i female from an Nii3H haul fished at 700-550 m depth<tei:lb/>off Fuerteventura (28N I4W) on 24 November 1963. 3 females from 2 RMT i<tei:lb/>hauls fished at 600-410 m depth in a position i8N 25W on 15 and 16 November<tei:lb/>1969.          <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 18) : Body length 1-98-2-20 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>2-09 mm (4 specimens). The cephalothorax is 4-1 times as long as the 4-segmented<tei:lb/>abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment are fused ; thoracic segments 4 and 5<tei:lb/>are separate. The rostrum is large and has two filaments which are thickened</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 18. Amallothrix altera ?. a, body, dorsal ; b, rostrum, half lateral ; c, rostrum,<tei:lb/>ventral ; d, last thoracic segment and abdomen, lateral ; e, and antenna ; f, mandibular<tei:lb/>palp ; g, ist maxilla ; h, and maxilla ; i, maxilliped ; j, ist leg ; k, and leg ; 1, 3rd leg ;<tei:lb/>m, 4th leg ; n, 5th leg.
