      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>33 2 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>basally. The last thoracic segment protrudes laterally. The genital segment is<tei:lb/>slightly longer than the combined length of the three subsequent segments. The<tei:lb/>furcal rami are about i times as long as wide. The ist antenna has 24 segments<tei:lb/>(the last is very small), and reaches to the hind edge of the genital segment. The<tei:lb/>remaining mouthparts are as shown. The endopodite of the 2nd maxilla has five<tei:lb/>brush-like setae, of which two are enlarged, and three flattened worm-like setae.<tei:lb/>The maxilliped has a large brush-like seta on the ist basipodite. The legs are as<tei:lb/>shown. The endopodite of the ist leg has no lobe and no surface spines. The 5th<tei:lb/>leg has three segments on each side.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The present females have been compared with the type specimens of<tei:lb/>Amallophora alter a held in the collections of the British Museum (Natural History).<tei:lb/>They are smaller than Farran's types but are structurally identical except that the<tei:lb/>holotype has two setae on the basipodite of the mandibular palp and no apparent<tei:lb/>segmentation line between endopodite segments 4 and 5 of the maxilliped. Farran<tei:lb/>(1929) could not ascertain the structure of the sensory setae of the 2nd maxilla.<tei:lb/>However, both holotype and paratype are identical to the females described here<tei:lb/>and have two large brush-like setae and three smaller ones. There is no doubt that<tei:lb/>the present females are conspecific with Amallophora alter a Farran.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The identity of this species is confused and it has been mixed up with Amallothrix<tei:lb/>auropecten (Giesbrecht, 1892). For comparison the latter species is described below<tei:lb/>(p. 333). Bradford (1973) described as Amallophora altera a species having one very<tei:lb/>large and four small brush-like setae on its 2nd maxilla. This arrangement is<tei:lb/>conspicuously different from both the present material and Farran's types.<tei:lb/>Bradford's specimen is incompletely described but it also differs from Amallothrix<tei:lb/>altera in the structure of its rostrum, its ist maxilla and in its ist and 5th legs. It is<tei:lb/>clearly a different species. Bradford used her specimen to typify a group containing<tei:lb/>Amallophora smithae Grice, 1962, Scolecithrix vorax Esterley, 1911 and Xanthocalanus<tei:lb/>typicus Farran, 1908. This group of species is considered here to comprise a new<tei:lb/>genus which is described later on p. 335. The true Amallothrix altera does not belong<tei:lb/>in this new genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vervoort's (1957) description is also incomplete but his specimens differ from the<tei:lb/>present species by (a) a short outer edge spine on the ist exopodite segment of the<tei:lb/>2nd leg, (b) an incompletely segmented 5th leg, (c) differences in the setation of<tei:lb/>the ist maxilla and (d) apparent differences in the endopodite of the 2nd maxilla,<tei:lb/>although the description is not very clear on this. These specimens may be A.<tei:lb/>auropecten but their identification cannot be certain from his description. Similarly<tei:lb/>the definite identity of his 1951 specimen cannot be determined. It has a 3-seg-<tei:lb/>mented 5th leg but Vervoort (1957) stated that it was conspecific with his later<tei:lb/>material. In 1965 Vervoort described a further specimen which may be Amallothrix<tei:lb/>altera, but the rostrum appears to be smaller and the endopod of the 2nd maxilla is<tei:lb/>different, although this may be due to the difficulty in seeing the small brush-like<tei:lb/>heads.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A . altera is generally similar to A . auropecten (Fig. 19) but differs in the following<tei:lb/>respects, (a) the rostrum of A . altera is larger and of a different shape, (b) the setation<tei:lb/>of the ist maxilla is different, especially of the exopodite, (c) the endopodite of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 333</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2nd maxilla has two of the five brush-like setae enlarged in A. alter a but not in<tei:lb/>A. auropecten, (d) the ist basipodite of the maxilliped has a large brush-like seta in<tei:lb/>A. altera but not in A. auropecten, (e) the endopod of the ist leg has a comb of<tei:lb/>surface spines in A. auropecten but not in A. altera, and (f) the 5th leg has three<tei:lb/>segments in A. altera but is incompletely segmented in A. auropecten. This last<tei:lb/>difference may be variable but all the examined specimens of A. altera have a<tei:lb/>completely segmented 5th pair of legs whereas those of A. auropecten are normally<tei:lb/>2-segmented or incompletely divided into three (Fig. 19 and see Giesbrecht, 1892 ;<tei:lb/>Rose, 1942 ; Wilson, 1942, 1950 ; Park, 1968 ; Bradford, 1973). One of the<tei:lb/>present specimens of A. auropecten has an abnormal 5th pair of legs similar to that<tei:lb/>figured by Park (1968, pi. 9, fig. 3).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In 1965 Vervoort transferred Farran's Amallophora altera to Amallothrix. The<tei:lb/>main apparent difference between the species and Bradford's redefinition of Amallo-<tei:lb/>thrix is its Scaphocalanus-type ist maxilla with three surface setae on the ist inner<tei:lb/>lobe. This character is shared with A. lobophora (p. 329) and A. auropecten (p. 334)<tei:lb/>and discussion of the affinities of all three species follows on p. 334. The enlargement<tei:lb/>of two of the brush-like setae in the present species is not, by itself, a generic character<tei:lb/>and it is shown by several other species and genera within the Scolecithricidae<tei:lb/>(see, for example, A. falcifer, p. 325, Scolecithricella obscura, p. 318, Scaphocalanus<tei:lb/>difficilis, p. 315, and Scopalatum dubia, p. 338).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amallothrix auropecten (Giesbrecht, 1892)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithrix auropecten Giesbrecht, 1892 : 266, pi. 13, figs 8, 18, 22, 27, pi. 37, figs 3, 10.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithricella auropecten ; Rose, 1933 : 158-9, fig. 175.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5. sp. i (part) Roe, igj2a : 296, 304, 310 ; I972C : 540.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>? Amallophora altera ; Vervoort, 1957 : 94-5, figs 77-79.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>? not Scolecithricella (Amallothrix) auropecten ; Vervoort, 1951 : 101-3, fig- 54-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 2 females and 21 males taken in n Nii3H hauls made<tei:lb/>at 950-475 m depth off Fuerteventura (28N I4W), between 24 and 28 November<tei:lb/>1965. 6 females and 6 males taken in 7 RMT I hauls made at 785-300 m depth in<tei:lb/>a position i8N 25W, between 13 and 16 November 1969.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION (Fig. 19) : Body length of the females is 1-9-2-05 mm with a mean<tei:lb/>of 1-96 mm (7 specimens) ; of the males it is 2-20-2-51 mm with a mean of 2-28 mm<tei:lb/>(21 specimens). The present females agree with the descriptions of Giesbrecht<tei:lb/>(1892) and Rose (1942). They are figured here for comparison with A. altera (p. 330)<tei:lb/>where their structure is commented upon. The endopod of the 2nd maxilla has<tei:lb/>five brush-like setae, all with small heads, but only four could be seen in the specimen<tei:lb/>illustrated. The males agree with Rose's account and redescription is unnecessary.<tei:lb/>The male described by Wilson (1950) as Scolecithricella auropecten is not of this<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Rose (1942) transferred Scolecithrix auropecten to Amallothrix.<tei:lb/>Bradford (1973) omitted it from her redefined Amallothrix and considered that it<tei:lb/>should typify an unnamed group, together with Scolecithrix laminata Farran, 1926</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>334</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>n</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 19. Amallothrix auropecten ?. a, body, dorsal ; b, rostrum, lateral ; c, rostrum,<tei:lb/>ventral ; d, last thoracic segment and abdomen, lateral ; e, 2nd antenna ; f, mandibular<tei:lb/>palp ; g, ist maxilla ; h, and maxilla ; i, maxilliped ; j, ist leg ; k, 2nd leg ; 1, 3rd leg ;<tei:lb/>m, 4th leg ; n, 5th leg. Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and Scolecithricella modica Tanaka, 1962. Scolecithrix (= Scolecithricella} laminata<tei:lb/>differs in many respects from the present species (see p. 320) and is not, in my<tei:lb/>opinion, closely related. A. altera and A. lobophora, however, do seem to be related<tei:lb/>to the present species. All three differ from Bradford's Amallothrix in having a<tei:lb/>Scaphocalanus-type ist maxilla (p. 329). The female 5th legs of all three species<tei:lb/>and the male 5th legs of A . lobophora and A . auropecten are also atypical of this genus.<tei:lb/>There are, however, differences between these three species. A. altera and A.<tei:lb/>auropecten are distinct (p. 332), and A. lobophora differs from both by lacking an</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 335</tei:p>
         <tei:p>outer edge spine on the ist exopodite segment of the ist leg and by having spines<tei:lb/>on the ist basipodite of the 3rd leg. The rostrum of A . lobophora is similar to that of<tei:lb/>A . alter a but the structure of its 5th legs (both sexes) , the spiny lobe on the endopod<tei:lb/>of the ist leg, and the uniformly small brush-like setae on the female 2nd maxilla are<tei:lb/>all more like A. auropecten. Whether or not these three species are sufficiently alike<tei:lb/>and sufficiently distinct from others to stand as a separate genus within the Scole-<tei:lb/>cithricidae is not yet clear. Discovery of the male of A . alter a and determination of<tei:lb/>the acceptable generic limits, especially regarding the ist maxilla, will clarify their<tei:lb/>position. Meanwhile all three species can conveniently remain within Amallothrix.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SCOPALATUM gen. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Head and ist thoracic segment fused ; thoracic segments 4 and 5<tei:lb/>fused or separate. Rostrum with two filaments, ist antenna with 23 segments in<tei:lb/>the female, 20 in the male ; there are large sensory filaments on the proximal<tei:lb/>segments of the male ist antenna. 2nd antenna exopod slightly longer than the<tei:lb/>endopod. ist maxilla with two posterior surface setae on the ist inner lobe, two<tei:lb/>setae on the 2nd inner lobe and four on the 3rd inner lobe ; in the female the endopod<tei:lb/>is ornamented with spinules. 2nd maxilla endopod with five brush-like setae and<tei:lb/>three flattened worm-like setae ; in the female one of the brush-like setae is greatly<tei:lb/>enlarged ; in the male two are enlarged. MaxiUiped with one brush-like seta on the<tei:lb/>ist basipodite. The male mouthparts are weakly chitinized and slightly reduced.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ist leg has a 3-segmented exopod and a single endopodite segment : all three<tei:lb/>exopodite segments have an outer spine ; the endopod has a lobe carrying small<tei:lb/>spines. 2nd leg has a 3-segmented exopod and a 2-segmented endopod ; the outer<tei:lb/>edge spines on all exopodite segments are large ; the 2nd and 3rd exopodite segments<tei:lb/>and the 2nd endopodite segment carry prominent surface spines. 3rd leg has a<tei:lb/>3-segmented exopodite and endopodite : the ist basipodite segment has a group of<tei:lb/>long spines ; the 2nd and 3rd exopodite and endopodite segments have surface<tei:lb/>spines. 4th leg has a 3-segmented exopodite and endopodite : the ist basipodite<tei:lb/>may have a group of long spines ; the 2nd and 3rd endopodite segments have very<tei:lb/>few small surface spines ; the exopodite segments have no surface spines. Female<tei:lb/>5th leg is uniramous ; on each side there are two segments, which may be fused,<tei:lb/>attached to a common basal segment ; there are 1-3 spines. Male $th leg similar<tei:lb/>to that of Scaphocalanus : left exopod is shorter than the endopod ; right exopod is<tei:lb/>much longer than the endopod.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scopalatum gibbera sp. nov. is nominated as the type species of the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The name Scopalatum is derived from the Latin scopae - a broom and latum -<tei:lb/>carried ; it refers to the sensory setae of the 2nd maxilla.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. T. Scott (1894) described a new subgenus, Amallophora, for a male<tei:lb/>copepod, A. typica, having a peculiar enlarged sensory seta on its 2nd maxilla.<tei:lb/>Giesbrecht (1892) had previously described a similar structure in the male of<tei:lb/>Xanthocalanus and considered that Amallophora was a junior synonym of Xantho-<tei:lb/>calanus (Giesbrecht &amp; Schmeil, 1898). Farran (1908) named a female which he<tei:lb/>believed to be conspecific with Scott's male as X. typicus. Recently, Bradford</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>336 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1973) separated these two specimens, reiterating Giesbrecht's opinion that Scott's<tei:lb/>male is a xanthocalanid but transferring Farran's female to the Scolecithricidae.<tei:lb/>She placed this, as X. typicus Farran, into a group together with Amallophora<tei:lb/>smithae Grice, 1962, Scolecithrix vorax Esterley, 1911 and Amallophora altera Farran,<tei:lb/>1929. Her inclusion of A. altera in this group however is erroneous, see p. 332 ;<tei:lb/>Bradford's specimen of A. altera is not conspecific with Farran's, which belongs to<tei:lb/>an entirely different group. Nevertheless, I believe she was correct in collecting<tei:lb/>together her specimen of 'A . altera' and the other three species into a distinct group<tei:lb/>within the Scolecithricidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bradford briefly characterized this group but did not name it as a separate genus.<tei:lb/>The discovery of a female of a new species which clearly belongs in this group (see<tei:lb/>below) and the redescription of what, in my opinion, is a male of this group (p. 338)<tei:lb/>lead me to believe that this collection of species should be given generic status<tei:lb/>within the Scolecithricidae. This new genus is denned above (p. 335). The genus<tei:lb/>Scopalatum at present contains 5. farrani sp. nov., 5. vorax (Esterley, 1911), 5.<tei:lb/>smithae (Grice, 1962), 5. dubia (T. Scott, 1894) and 5. gibber a sp. nov. It also<tei:lb/>includes the species 'Amallophora altera' wrongly identified by Bradford (1973)<tei:lb/>which should be further described and named. Grice's (1962) account of S. smithae<tei:lb/>is complete and also conforms with the new genus. The descriptions of 5. vorax<tei:lb/>(Esterley, 1911) and 'A. altera' of Bradford (1973) are incomplete, however, par-<tei:lb/>ticularly regarding the swimming legs. The present generic definition may have to<tei:lb/>be modified when these latter two species are fully described. Details of S. gibbera<tei:lb/>sp. nov., 5. farrani sp. nov. and 5. dubia (T. Scott, 1894) are given below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scopalatum agrees in all respects with Bradford's (1973) redefinition of the<tei:lb/>Scolecithricidae. The combination of characters given on p. 335, especially those<tei:lb/>of the ist and 2nd maxillae and the legs, distinguishes this new genus from all<tei:lb/>others in the family. It is related to A . altera, A . auropecten and A . lobophora, see<tei:lb/>p. 334. These three species may have to be removed from Amallothrix but they<tei:lb/>differ from the present genus in the structure of their ist maxilla and, in the females,<tei:lb/>of the 2nd maxilla. The 2nd maxilla of the male A. auropecten is also distinct, and<tei:lb/>both this species and A. altera are further distinguished by having no basipodite<tei:lb/>spines on either their 3rd or 4th legs. A. lobophora has a similar 2nd maxilla in the<tei:lb/>male to Scopalatum and both sexes have a group of spines on the ist basipodite of<tei:lb/>the 3rd leg. They do not, however, have an external spine on all exopodite segments<tei:lb/>of the ist leg.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scopalatum gibbera sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amallophora sp. Roe, 19720 : 295, 309.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : i female in an Nii3H haul fished at 310-240 m depth off<tei:lb/>Fuerteventura (28N I4W) on 13 November 1965. 2 females in 2 RMT i hauls<tei:lb/>fished in a position i8N 25W ; one (the holotype) caught at 300-210 m depth on<tei:lb/>12 November 1969 and the other at 400-305 m depth on 17 November 1969.<tei:lb/>Deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), holotype reg. no. 1974 : 620,<tei:lb/>paratypes reg. no. 1974 : 621-622.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>337</tei:p>
         <tei:p>m</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 20. Scopalatum gibbera ?. a, body, dorsal ; b, body, lateral ; c, rostrum, ventral ;<tei:lb/>d, ist antenna ; e, 2nd antenna ; f, mandible ; g, ist maxilla ; h, 2nd maxilla, exopod ;<tei:lb/>i, 2nd maxilla, endopod ; j, maxilliped ; k, ist leg ; 1, 2nd leg ; m, 2nd leg, exopodite<tei:lb/>segments 2-3 (paratype) ; n, 3rd leg ; o, 4th leg ; p, 5th leg. Bar scale o-i mm unless<tei:lb/>indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>33 8 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 20) : Body length 2-58-2-81 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>2-73 mm (3 specimens). The holotype measures 2-81 mm. The cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>robust and 3-9 times as long as the 5-segmented abdomen. The head and ist<tei:lb/>thoracic segment are fused, as are thoracic segments 4 and 5. The mid-dorsal<tei:lb/>region of the head has a very characteristic protuberance which is particularly<tei:lb/>conspicuous when seen from the side. The rostrum has two filaments with thickened<tei:lb/>bases. The hind margin of the cephalothorax is deeply indented laterally. The<tei:lb/>genital segment has a slight ventral protrusion and is longer than the combined<tei:lb/>length of the three following segments. The furcal rami are about as long as wide.<tei:lb/>The ist antenna has 23 segments and does not quite reach the end of the cephalo-<tei:lb/>thorax. The remaining mouthparts and the legs are as shown. The endopod of the<tei:lb/>ist maxilla is covered with small spines. The endopodite of the 2nd maxilla has<tei:lb/>five brush-like and three flattened worm-like setae, one of the brush-like setae is<tei:lb/>greatly enlarged. The ist basipodite of the maxilliped has one brush-like seta.<tei:lb/>The ist basipodite of the 3rd leg has two conspicuous groups of long spines. The<tei:lb/>terminal spines on legs 2-4 have laminae. The 5th pair of legs is uniramous with<tei:lb/>two fused segments on each side attached to a basal segment ; the line of fusion is<tei:lb/>clearly visible. The terminal segment on each side has one long and one shorter<tei:lb/>spine. There is an additional small spine on one side only, but this is clearly variable<tei:lb/>since in one of the paratypes it is about halfway down the outside edge of the fused<tei:lb/>2nd and 3rd segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. 5. gibbera has all the female characters defined for the genus on p.<tei:lb/>335. A discussion of its affinities has been given earlier.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scopalatum farrani sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthocalanus typicus ; Farran, 1908 : 47-48, pi. 4, figs 15-17 ; Bradford, 1973 : 145.<tei:lb/>Amallophora typica ; Sars, 1924 : pi. 38, figs 8-18 ; 1925 : 140-142 (part) ; Rose, 1933 : 134-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>135 (part), fig. 129 ; Wilson, 1942 : 170-171, fig. i ; Wilson, 1950 : 159 (part), pi. 20, fig. 275 ;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vervoort, 1957 : 94-95 (part) ; Tanaka, 1960 : 102 (part) ; Vervoort, 1965 : 27-28 (part) ;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Binet &amp; Dessier, 1971 : 430, 453 ; Bradford, 1973 : 138-139 (part).<tei:lb/>? Amallophora typica ; Grice &amp; Hulsemann 1965 -.221, 223 ; Harding, 1972 : 58.<tei:lb/>not Xanthocalanus typicus ; Giesbrecht, 1897 : 254 ; Giesbrecht &amp; Schmeil, 1898 : 50 ; Wolfen-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>den, 1908 : 35.<tei:lb/>not Amallophora typica T. Scott, 1894 : 54, pi. 3, figs 39-46, pi. 6, figs 1-4 ; A. Scott, 1909 : 85,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pi. 36, figs 1-8.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female described by Farran (1908) as X. typicus was misidentified and belongs<tei:lb/>to a new species which I have named Scopalatum farrani. The female specimens of<tei:lb/>S. farrani in the collections of the Institute of Oceanographic Sciences agree com-<tei:lb/>pletely with the generic definition of Scopalatum given earlier.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scopalatum dubia (T. Scott, 1894)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amallophora dubia T. Scott, 1894 : 55, pi. 4, figs 10-18.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecithrix scotti Giesbrecht, 1897 : 254 ; Giesbrecht &amp; Schmeil, 1898 : 46 ; Wolfenden, 1911 :<tei:lb/>250.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 339</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heteramalla dubia ; Sars, 1907 : 17 (part) ; A. Scott, 1909 : 86-87 (part) ; Sars, 1925 : 142-144<tei:lb/>(part) ; Rose, 1933 : 135 (part) ; Alzamora, 1940 : 6 ; Wilson, 1942 : 189 (part) ; Vervoort,<tei:lb/>1965 : 28-30 (part).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heleremalla dubia ; Rose, 1929 : 26.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hetermalla dubia ; Roe, 19720 : 303, 309.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>? Heteramalla dubia ; Wilson, 1950 : 239 ; Grice &amp; Hulsemann, 1967 : 16.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>not Heteramalla dubia ; A. Scott, 1909 : pi. 33, figs 1-9 ; Sars, 1924 : pi. 39 ; Rose, 1933 : fig.<tei:lb/>130 ; Grice &amp; Hulsemann, 1965 : 221, 223, 235.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : i male in an Nii3H haul made at 660-510 m depth off<tei:lb/>Fuerteventura (28N I4W) on 26 November 1965. 8 males taken in 5 RMT i<tei:lb/>hauls made at 900-305 m depth in a position i8N 25W between 12 and 17 Novem-<tei:lb/>ber 1969. 7 males deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no.<tei:lb/>1974 : 623-629.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 21) : Body length 2-36-2-74 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>2-48 mm (9 specimens). The cephalothorax is 2-7 times as long as the 5-segmented<tei:lb/>abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment are fused ; thoracic segments 4 and<tei:lb/>5 are separate. The rostrum has two filaments attached to a common base. The<tei:lb/>hind margin of the cephalothorax has a slight lateral indentation. The ist antenna<tei:lb/>reaches to the hind edge of the 2nd abdominal segment ; both ist antennae have<tei:lb/>20 segments and the proximal 12 segments on each side carry large flattened sensory<tei:lb/>filaments. The mouthparts and legs are as shown. The endopod of the 2nd<tei:lb/>maxilla has five brush-like setae and three flattened worm-like setae ; the heads of<tei:lb/>three of the brush-like setae are small whereas two are greatly enlarged - one of them<tei:lb/>especially so. All the 'brush' heads consist of fine threads ending in rounded<tei:lb/>swellings. The ist basipodite of the 3rd leg has two groups of long narrow spines.<tei:lb/>The 5th pair of legs is similar to that of Scaphocalanus and reaches back to the end<tei:lb/>of the furcal rami. On the right leg the exopodite terminates in a claw-like segment.<tei:lb/>On the left leg the exopodite is shorter than the endopodite ; the 3rd exopodite<tei:lb/>segment is covered with hairs and has a terminal lamella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. I have compared the present males with the type specimens of Amallo-<tei:lb/>phora dubia T. Scott, 1894 held in the collections of the British Museum (Natural<tei:lb/>History). The type material consists of several slides on which are mounted the<tei:lb/>mixed appendages and abdomens of two specimens. There is only one example of<tei:lb/>most appendages - including the 2nd maxilla, and there is no specimen of the ist<tei:lb/>maxilla. Neither of the two cephalosomes is in the Museum's collection. The<tei:lb/>material is very faded and it is impossible to ascertain the detailed structure of some<tei:lb/>of the appendages. An attempt to remount some of the specimens failed because<tei:lb/>the mountant would not dissolve. The only observable difference between the<tei:lb/>present males and Scott's type is in the 3rd leg where the type does not, apparently,<tei:lb/>have spines on the ist basipodite. This limb is figured by Scott but wrongly<tei:lb/>described as the 4th leg (Scott, 1894 : PL 4, fig. 16). According to Scott the right<tei:lb/>ist antenna has 18 joints and is indistinctly geniculate and the left ist antenna has<tei:lb/>23 joints. There are three ist antennae in the type collection ; one has 19 segments<tei:lb/>but the others are very faded and have, I believe, 20 and 21 segments respectively.<tei:lb/>None of these antennae are in any way geniculate and their segmentation agrees</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>340</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>u</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 21. Scopalatum dubia $. a, body, dorsal ; b, rostrum and forehead, lateral ; c,<tei:lb/>rostrum, ventral ; d, last thoracic segment, lateral ; e, ist antenna ; f, and antenna ;<tei:lb/>g, mandibular palp ; h, mandible blade ; i, ist maxilla ; j, ist maxilla (different<tei:lb/>specimen) ; k, 2nd maxilla ; 1, 2nd maxilla, head of small brush-like seta ; m, maxilliped,<tei:lb/>basal segment (different specimen) ; n, ist leg ; o, 2nd leg ; p, 3rd leg ; q, 4th leg ; r,<tei:lb/>5th leg ; s, 5th leg, last exopodite segment right leg ; t, 5th leg, last exopodite segment<tei:lb/>left leg; u, 5th leg, last endopodite segment left leg (different specimen). Bar scale<tei:lb/>o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 341</tei:p>
         <tei:p>better with the present male's antennae, which have 20 segments on each side, than<tei:lb/>with Scott's description. The type material of the 2nd maxilla is in very poor<tei:lb/>condition and it is impossible to see any structure except the general presence of two<tei:lb/>large brush-like setae. Despite the possible difference in the 3rd leg I believe that<tei:lb/>the present males are conspecific with Scott's Amallophora dubia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sars (1907) erected a genus, Heteramalla, for a female which he believed was<tei:lb/>conspecific with Scott's male. In 1925, however, he expressed doubts as to the<tei:lb/>correctness of his assumption, and in 1965 Vervoort also mentioned the possibility<tei:lb/>that Sars' females and Scott's male were not the same species. Further male<tei:lb/>specimens have been recorded by Wolfenden (1911) and by Rose (1929) but they<tei:lb/>were not described.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bradford (1973) transferred Heteramalla from the Phaennidae to the Scolecithridae.<tei:lb/>The present males are clearly scolecithricids according to her redefinition of the<tei:lb/>family. I have examined female specimens of H. dubia Sars, 1907 taken at 1020-<tei:lb/>800 m depth in a position i8N 25W. These specimens agree with Sars' (1924,<tei:lb/>1925) description except that they have no 5th pair of legs (thereby conforming<tei:lb/>with Grice &amp; Hulsemann's (1965) specimen), and there is no seta on the 2nd inner<tei:lb/>lobe of the ist maxilla. The endopod of the 3rd leg has two segments only. These<tei:lb/>females also agree with Bradford's definition of the Scolecithricidae. I believe,<tei:lb/>however, that Sars was mistaken in identifying his female with Scott's male. Apart<tei:lb/>from the normal sexual differences they differ in the following respects : (a) the<tei:lb/>rostrum of $ H. dubia is strong and plate-like, in the male it has two filaments,<tei:lb/>(b) the ist maxilla of the males has two setae on the surface of the ist inner lobe,<tei:lb/>two on the 2nd inner lobe and four on the 3rd inner lobe ; the corresponding number<tei:lb/>of setae in the female are i, o and 3, (c) the ist leg of $ H. dubia has a 2-segmented<tei:lb/>exopod with no external spine on the ist exopodite segment ; the endopod has no<tei:lb/>lobe and has a group of large spines ; in the male the ist leg has three exopodite<tei:lb/>segments, all with outer spines, and the endopod has a lobe with a comb of small<tei:lb/>spines only, (d) $ H. dubia has no surface spines on the exopodites of legs 2-4-<tei:lb/>these legs are heavily spinulated in the male, and (e) the 3rd leg of the $ H. dubia<tei:lb/>has a 2-segmented endopod and has no spines on the ist basipodite segment ; the<tei:lb/>3rd leg of the male has three endopodite segments and two groups of spines on the<tei:lb/>ist basipodite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I agree with Bradford (1973) that the genus Heteramalla Sars, 1907 belongs to<tei:lb/>the Scolecithricidae. It is at present a monospecific genus known only from the<tei:lb/>female (see p. 342). Scott's male is here considered to belong to the new genus<tei:lb/>Scopalatum described on p. 335.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most striking difference between S. dubia and the females of Scopalatum is in<tei:lb/>the development of the sensory setae of the 2nd maxilla. The females have one<tei:lb/>brush-like seta much enlarged but the male has two. Enlargement of one or two of<tei:lb/>these setae is, however, common to the males of many species and genera of the<tei:lb/>Scolecithricidae (see, for example, Amallothrix falcifer, p. 325, and Scolecithricella<tei:lb/>dentata (Rose, 1942 : 55). I believe that the increased size of one seta in the<tei:lb/>present males is a sexual character. Apart from the normal sexual differences in<tei:lb/>the ist antenna and more weakly chitinized and slightly reduced mouthparts, the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>342 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>appendages of these males are very similar to those of the female 5. gibber a sp. nov.,<tei:lb/>5. farrani sp. nov. and 5. smithae Grice, 1962. They are so similar to 5. gibbera<tei:lb/>that these two species may be conspecific. They differ in the length of the outer<tei:lb/>edge spines of the exopodite of the ist leg, and the males do not have the curious<tei:lb/>dorsal swelling of the female. In addition to these differences 5. farrani has groups<tei:lb/>of spines on the ist basipodite of the 4th leg. 5. smithae and S. vorax are much<tei:lb/>smaller species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heteramalla sarsi sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heteramalla dubia ; Sars, 1907 : 17 (part) ; A. Scott, 1909 : 86-87 (P ar t)&gt; pi. 33, figs 1-9 ;<tei:lb/>Sars, 1924 : pi. 39 ; 1925 : 142-144 (part) ; Rose, 1933 : 135 (part) fig. 130 ; Wilson, 1942 :<tei:lb/>189 (part) ; Grice &amp; Hulsemann, 1965 : 221, 223, 235 ; Vervoort, 1965 : 28-30 (part).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>? Heteramalla dubia ; Wilson, 1950 : 239 ; Grice &amp; Hulsemann, 1967 : 16.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>not Heteramalla dubia : Alzamora, 1940 : 6.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female described by Sars (1907) as H. dubia was misidentified and belongs to a<tei:lb/>new species which I have named H. sarsi. The validity of this species is considered<tei:lb/>earlier together with the discussion of Scopalatum dubia (T. Scott).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family METRIDIIDAE<tei:lb/>Metridia alata sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 6 females and 6 males taken in 6 RMT i hauls made at<tei:lb/>1220-700 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 12 and 18 November 1969.<tei:lb/>The holotype (female) and allotype (male) were caught on 18 November 1969 at<tei:lb/>i22O-iooom. Deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), holotype<tei:lb/>reg. no. 1974 : 630, paratypes reg. no. 1974 : 631-641.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 22) : Body length 8-64-10-24 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>9-09 mm (5 specimens). The holotype measures 9-12 mm. The cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>1-2 times as long as the 3-segmented abdomen. It is very robust and in lateral view<tei:lb/>the anterior part of the head protrudes sharply from the hind part. The right lateral<tei:lb/>margin of the head is produced into a very conspicuous wing ; this wing protrudes<tei:lb/>both laterally and ventrally and is present on the right side only. The head and ist<tei:lb/>thoracic segment are separate ; thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused. The rostrum<tei:lb/>has two strong spikes pointing ventrally. The hind edge of the cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>smooth and rather abruptly rounded. The genital segment is swollen both laterally<tei:lb/>and ventrally and is longer than the combined length of the two subsequent segments.<tei:lb/>The furcal rami are 0-36 times the length of the abdomen and are 6 times longer than<tei:lb/>wide. The ist antenna is slightly longer than the body : it has 25 segments, seg-<tei:lb/>ments 7 and 8 are partially fused and the last segment is small ; the ist segment has<tei:lb/>three hooks and the 2nd, 4th and 5th segments each have a single hook. The<tei:lb/>remaining mouthparts and legs are as shown. The endopodite of the mandibular<tei:lb/>palp has a group of large spines on the ist segment and many small spines on the 2nd.<tei:lb/>The mandible blade has numerous small spines in addition to the large teeth. The</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>343</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 22. Metridia alata ?. a, body, dorsal ; b, body, lateral ; c, ist antenna, basal<tei:lb/>segments ; d, 2nd antenna ; e, mandibular palp ; f, mandible blade ; g, ist maxilla ;<tei:lb/>h, 2nd maxilla ; i, maxilliped ; j, ist leg ; k, 2nd leg ; 1, 3rd leg ; m, 4th leg ; n, 5th leg.<tei:lb/>Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>19</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>344 H - s - J- ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ist endopodite segment of the 2nd leg has three strong claws. The 5th pair of legs<tei:lb/>is symmetrical ; on each side the basipodite has a bunch of long hairs, the ist seg-<tei:lb/>ment has a plumose outer edge seta, the 2nd a short spine and the 3rd terminates<tei:lb/>with three plumose setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male (Fig. 23a-b) : Body length 8-00-8-64 mm wrt h a mean of 8-51 mm (6<tei:lb/>specimens) . The allotype measures 8-64 mm. The appearance of the cephalothorax<tei:lb/>is as in the female ; the head has a conspicuous wing on the right side only. The<tei:lb/>abdomen has five segments. The left ist antenna is geniculate ; both ist antennae<tei:lb/>are slightly longer than the body. The remaining mouthparts and swimming legs<tei:lb/>are as in the female. The 5th pair of legs is asymmetrical : on the left side, the basal<tei:lb/>segment is longer than the right and has a bundle of hairs, the 4th segment ter-<tei:lb/>minates with two small spines ; on the right side there are five segments, the 2nd<tei:lb/>bearing a long curved process and the 5th ending in three small spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The appendages of the present species are very similar to those of<tei:lb/>Metridia princeps Giesbrecht, 1892, but it can be distinguished easily from this and<tei:lb/>from all other species in the genus by the peculiar wing-like development of the right<tei:lb/>side of the head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family CENTROPAGIIDAE<tei:lb/>Centropages caribbeanensis Park, 1970</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 43 females and 21 males from 6 RMT i hauls made at<tei:lb/>194-0 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 15 and 18 November 1969. 5<tei:lb/>males are deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 :<tei:lb/>642-646.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 23c-e) : Body length 1-82-2-13 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>1-95 mm (15 specimens). The general appearance of the cephalothorax is as for the<tei:lb/>female ; it is 2-2 times as long as the 5-segmented abdomen. The furcal rami are<tei:lb/>about 3 times longer than wide. The ist antenna exceeds the body length by three<tei:lb/>or four segments. The right ist antenna is geniculate and has 22 segments, segments<tei:lb/>17, 18 and the proximal part of 19 have a row of fine teeth, the hinged joint is<tei:lb/>between segments 18 and 19. The remaining mouthparts and swimming legs are<tei:lb/>as in the female. The 5th pair of legs is asymmetrical. On the right side the<tei:lb/>terminal exopodite segment forms a large chela ; on the left side the last exopodite<tei:lb/>segment has two large spine-like processes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The present males were found in the same hauls as females which<tei:lb/>agree in every respect with Park's (1970) description. The male is similar to that<tei:lb/>of C. elegans Giesbrecht, 1895 described by Park (1968). It can be distinguished<tei:lb/>from this latter species by the 5th pair of legs. In C. caribbeanensis the spines on<tei:lb/>the terminal segment of the left exopodite are longer than in C. elegans and are not<tei:lb/>pitted distally. The shorter arm of the chelate right exopodite is pointed in C.<tei:lb/>caribbeanensis and rounded in C. elegans. The present specimens are only the second<tei:lb/>record of this species and the first from the eastern north Atlantic.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>345</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 23. a-b, Metridia alata &lt;$. a, body, dorsal ; b, 5th leg. c-e, Centropages carib-<tei:lb/>beanensis 3- c, body, dorsal ; d, last thoracic segment and abdomen, lateral ; e, 5th<tei:lb/>legs, f, Heterorhabdus vipera &lt;$ 5th legs, g, Heterorhabdus tenuis &lt;$ 5th legs, h-k,<tei:lb/>Haloptilus angusticeps &lt;$. h, body, dorsal ; i, forehead and rostrum, lateral ; j, last<tei:lb/>thoracic segment and abdomen, lateral ; k, 5th legs. Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>346 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family HETERORHABDIDAE<tei:lb/>Heterorhabdus vipera (Giesbrecht, 1892)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 14 females and 4 males from 12 Nii3H hauls fished at<tei:lb/>590-90 m depth off Fuerteventura (28N i4W), between n and 26 November<tei:lb/>1965. 22 females and 3 males from 12 RMT i hauls made at 1250-110 m depth in<tei:lb/>a position i8N 25W between 12 and 17 November 1969.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The males of H. vipera and H. tenuis Tanaka, 1964 have been confused.<tei:lb/>Park (1970) described the male of H. tenuis as H. vipera (Roe, 1972^), and since the<tei:lb/>present material includes both species it seems advisable to illustrate the differences<tei:lb/>in their fifth pair of legs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. vipera (Fig. 23f) has a strongly asymmetric fifth pair of legs. The endopodites<tei:lb/>consist of three segments on both sides and have been omitted for clarity. The 3rd<tei:lb/>exopodite segment of the right leg is abruptly terminated and about as long as the<tei:lb/>combined length of the two previous segments. The present specimens differ<tei:lb/>slightly from that of Giesbrecht (1892) by having a spine on the 2nd basipodite<tei:lb/>segment of both legs, and by having an outer edge spine on the 2nd exopodite of the<tei:lb/>right leg. The similarity is such that I have no doubt that they are conspecific.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heterorhabdus tenuis Tanaka, 1964</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heterorhabdus vipera ; Park, 1970 : 523-525, figs 250-252 (male only).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 7 males from 5 Nii3H hauls made at 660-460 m depth off<tei:lb/>Fuerteventura (28N 14 W), between u and 26 November 1965. 14 males from<tei:lb/>6 RMT i hauls made at 600-210 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 12 and<tei:lb/>16 November 1969.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The present males agree with the descriptions of Tanaka (1964) and<tei:lb/>Park (1970 - as H. vipera &lt;$}. The differences in the fifth pair of legs between H.<tei:lb/>tenuis and H. vipera can be seen clearly by comparing Figs 23g and 23f. In H.<tei:lb/>tenuis the 2nd basipodite of the left leg has a haired inner margin and the 3rd<tei:lb/>exopodite segment of the right leg is a totally different shape to that of H. vipera.<tei:lb/>Both endopodites have three segments and are omitted for clarity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family AUGAPTILIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several of the genera in this family, particularly Euaugaptilus, have recently<tei:lb/>been reviewed by Matthews (1972). Because of the high degree of intraspecific<tei:lb/>variation within this genus he used a system of numerical taxonomy, based upon<tei:lb/>35 structural characters, to identify the various species. Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974)<tei:lb/>also used a similar list of 21 characters to identify the Euaugaptilus spp. off Izu,<tei:lb/>Japan. These latter authors also recognized the great variation within species in<tei:lb/>this genus but retained a normal diagnostic key for their identification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several species of Euaugaptilus are described here, and all of them show marked<tei:lb/>intraspecific variations. This variability emphasizes the difficulties in recognizing<tei:lb/>or describing species based upon single specimens. Some Euaugaptilus species are</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 347</tei:p>
         <tei:p>so similar to one another (see, for example, Matthews, 1972 : 66), that the discovery<tei:lb/>and description of more specimens is needed before firm conclusions can be reached<tei:lb/>regarding their validity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haloptilus angusticeps Sars, 1907</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 2 males and 7 females from 5 Nii3H hauls made at<tei:lb/>625-0 m depth off Fuerteventura (28N I4W), between 17 and 26 November 1965.<tei:lb/>12 females from 5 RMT I hauls made at 700-305 m depth in a position i8N 25W,<tei:lb/>between 14 and 17 November 1969. The males are deposited at the British Museum<tei:lb/>(Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 647-648.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 23h-k) : Body length 3-04-3-12 mm. The cephalo-<tei:lb/>thorax is long and slender and slightly more than 4 times as long as the 5-segmented<tei:lb/>abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment are separate ; thoracic segments 4<tei:lb/>and 5 are fused. The rostral base is rounded and bears two fine fairly long filaments.<tei:lb/>The hind margin of the cephalothorax is smoothly rounded. The ist antennae<tei:lb/>reach to the end of the furcal rami ; the left ist antenna is geniculate and has 20<tei:lb/>segments, the hinge joint is in segment 18. The remaining mouthparts and swim-<tei:lb/>ming legs are similar to those of the female. The 5th pair of legs is slightly asym-<tei:lb/>metrical. On each side, the ist basipodite segment has a pointed projection which<tei:lb/>is larger on the left, and the 2nd basipodite has a patch of hairs. Both endopods<tei:lb/>have three segments and are omitted here for clarity. The 2nd and 3rd exopodite<tei:lb/>segments are almost fused and only a faint line of separation remains. On the left<tei:lb/>side the 3rd exopodite segment has three small spines (the outer one is missing on the<tei:lb/>illustrated specimen) ; on the right the 3rd exopodite has one long curved spine and<tei:lb/>two of medium length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Except for sexual differences these males agree so closely with the<tei:lb/>female H. angusticeps that there is no doubt that they are conspecific.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haloptilus paralongicirrus Park, 1970</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 8 males and 160 females from 7 RMT i hauls made at<tei:lb/>4~55 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 12 and 16 November 1969. 5<tei:lb/>males are deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 649-653.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 24) : Body length 1-67-2-20 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>i -87 mm (6 specimens). The shape of the cephalothorax is similar to that of the<tei:lb/>female. The head and ist thoracic segment are fused, as are thoracic segments 4<tei:lb/>and 5. In dorsal view the forehead is shaped like a rounded triangle, and in some<tei:lb/>specimens it is more rounded than shown here. The rostral filaments are fairly<tei:lb/>long and have swollen bases. The hind margin of the cephalothorax is smoothly<tei:lb/>rounded. The abdomen has five segments, the furcal rami are about twice as long<tei:lb/>as wide. The ist antennae are longer than the body. The left ist antenna is<tei:lb/>geniculate and has 21 segments ; the proximal 12-13 segments have long sensory<tei:lb/>setae, segments 16, 17 and 18 have an undulating lamella, and segment 18 contains</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 24. Haloptilus paralongicirrus &lt;J. a, thorax and abdomen, dorsal ; b, head, dorsal<tei:lb/>(different specimen) ; c, rostrum, lateral ; d, rostrum, ventral ; e, ist antenna, segments<tei:lb/>15-20 ; f, 2nd antenna ; g, mandibular palp ; h, mandible blade ; i, 2nd maxilla ;<tei:lb/>j, maxilliped ; k, ist leg ; 1, 2nd leg ; m, 5th legs (different specimen). Bar scale o-i mm<tei:lb/>unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the hinge joint. (The last segment is missing in the figure.) The remaining mouth-<tei:lb/>parts are very feebly chitinized and are similar in structure to those of the female.<tei:lb/>A satisfactory preparation of the ist maxilla could not be made. The 2nd, 3rd and<tei:lb/>4th pairs of legs are similar. The 5th pair of legs is slightly asymmetrical ; the<tei:lb/>pointed projection on the ist basipodite is larger on the left side, and the 2nd<tei:lb/>exopodite segment of the right leg bears a small haired lobe. Both endopodites<tei:lb/>have three segments and are omitted here for clarity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Haloptilus paralongicirrus was described from the female (Park, 1970)<tei:lb/>and is closely related to Haloptilus longicornis (Claus, 1863) and H. longicirrus<tei:lb/>Brodsky, 1950. The females of the present species differ from those of H . longicirrus<tei:lb/>only in the shape of the forehead and their smaller size. Park suggested that these<tei:lb/>very slight differences may only be variations caused by differences in their vertical<tei:lb/>distributions - H. longicirrus living deeper than H . paralongicirrus. The present<tei:lb/>collections contain females of all three species and the males of two (that of H .<tei:lb/>longicirrus is unknown). H. longicornis was the shallowest of the three and H.<tei:lb/>longicirrus the deepest. The mean body lengths of H. longicornis were 2-14 mm<tei:lb/>(females) and 1-18 mm (males), of H. paralongicirrus they were 2-59 mm (females)<tei:lb/>and 1-87 mm (males), and of H. longicirrus 3-08 mm (females). All three species</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 349</tei:p>
         <tei:p>were non-migrants. These results agree with those of Park (1970). The present<tei:lb/>males were found in association with female H. paralongicirrus and since their struc-<tei:lb/>ture, body size and depth distribution accord with those of the female I believe<tei:lb/>that they are conspecific.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus atlanticus sp. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 7 females and 2 males from 2 RMT i hauls made in a<tei:lb/>position i8N 25W ; one, containing the female holotype, at 400-305 m depth on<tei:lb/>17 November 1969 and the other, with the male allotype, at 400-300 m depth on<tei:lb/>13 November 1969. Deposited at the British Museum (Natural History), holotype<tei:lb/>reg. no. 1974 : 654, paratypes reg. no. 1974 : 655-662.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 25a-g) : Body length 2-81-2-96 mm with a mean of<tei:lb/>2-92 mm (7 specimens). The holotype measures 2-89 mm. The cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>long and slender and about 3-5 times as long as the 3-segmented abdomen. The<tei:lb/>head and ist thoracic segment are separate but thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused.<tei:lb/>In dorsal view the head protrudes slightly and is rounded. The rostrum has two<tei:lb/>fine short filaments. The hind margin of the cephalothorax is smoothly rounded.<tei:lb/>The genital segment is elongated and over twice as long as the combined length of<tei:lb/>the remaining two segments ; it is slightly swollen laterally and more distinctly<tei:lb/>so ventrally. The furcal rami are about twice as long as wide ; the inner furcal<tei:lb/>setae are almost as long as the cephalothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first antenna has 25 segments, the last five of which extend past the end of<tei:lb/>the body. The remaining mouthparts are as shown. The mandible blade has the<tei:lb/>same structure on both the right and left side. The swimming legs are identical<tei:lb/>in both sexes. The base of each external spine on the exopodite of the ist leg has<tei:lb/>a conspicuous comb of curved spines. The terminal exopodite spine on the 2nd,<tei:lb/>3rd and 4th leg is long and bears numerous small spinules. The 5th pair of legs is<tei:lb/>symmetrical. The 2nd basipodite has a very long seta which is longer than the<tei:lb/>remainder of the leg. The 2nd exopodite segment has a massive internal spine,<tei:lb/>carrying many coarse teeth, but no external spine. The endopodite has three<tei:lb/>segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male (Fig. 25h-m) : The allotype is slightly crushed and could not be measured ;<tei:lb/>the other male is 2-58 mm long. The general appearance is as for the female. The<tei:lb/>abdomen has five segments. The left ist antenna is geniculate but broken in both<tei:lb/>specimens, the right ist antenna reaches to the end of the furcal rami. The mouth-<tei:lb/>parts are identical to those of the female except that the exopodite of the 2nd<tei:lb/>antenna has three terminal setae not two, and the mandible blade on the right side<tei:lb/>has a minute extra tooth. The swimming legs are as shown, the 4th leg is similar<tei:lb/>to the 3rd. The 5th pair of legs is slightly asymmetrical. The ist exopodite seg-<tei:lb/>ment of the left leg has no outer spine and the 3rd exopodite segment of this leg has<tei:lb/>a short claw and a long curved spine. On the right leg the second exopodite segment<tei:lb/>has a haired lobe on its inner edge, and the terminal segment has three spines. On<tei:lb/>both legs the inner corner of the 2nd basipodite bears a curious structure shaped like<tei:lb/>a segmented hemisphere. The endopodites of both legs have three segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>350</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>m</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 25. a-g, Euaugaptilus atlanticus ?. a, body, dorsal ; b, forehead and rostrum,<tei:lb/>lateral ; c, 2nd antenna ; d, mandible right side ; e, 2nd maxilla ; f, maxilliped ; g, 5th<tei:lb/>leg. h-m, Euaugaptilus atlanticus $. h, ist maxilla ; i, ist leg ; j, ist leg, outer edge<tei:lb/>of exopodite segments i and 2 ; k, 2nd leg ; 1, 3rd leg ; m, 5th legs.       <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 351</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The female of E. atlanticus resembles that of E. longiseta Grice &amp;<tei:lb/>Hulsemann, 1965. I have examined the type specimen of this latter species at the<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History) and it differs from E. atlanticus in the structure<tei:lb/>of the mandible blade, the ist leg and the 2nd exopodite segment of the 5th leg.<tei:lb/>The male of E. longiseta is smaller than the present species and has a different 5th<tei:lb/>pair of legs. The copepodite E. sp. i Tanaka &amp; Omori, 1974, is also similar to the<tei:lb/>present species but it is larger and differs in the structure of the ist maxilla and<tei:lb/>mandible blade.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus fecundus Tanaka &amp; Omori, 1974</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus sp. 3 Grice &amp; Hulsemann, 1967 : 37, figs 231-240 ; Matthews, 1972 : 45.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED: i female from an RMT i haul made at 1250-1000 m<tei:lb/>depth in a position i8N 25W on 17 November 1969. Deposited at the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 663.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 26a-h) : Body length 6-40 mm. I was preparing<tei:lb/>to describe and name this specimen until I saw the recent account of E. fecundus.<tei:lb/>The present female differs from Tanaka &amp; Omori's specimen only in the following<tei:lb/>minor details, (a) the endopod of the 2nd antenna is about 4 times longer than the<tei:lb/>exopod, instead of 2-6 times, (b) there are 24 setae on the endopod of the 2nd<tei:lb/>maxilla instead of 19, and (c) the 3rd endopodite segment of the 2nd leg has seven<tei:lb/>setae instead of six. The setation of the distal segments of the maxilliped is<tei:lb/>slightly obscure in the present female but in all other respects it is identical to<tei:lb/>E. fecundus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. I believe that this species is the female of the male described as<tei:lb/>Euaugaptilus sp. 3 by Grice &amp; Hulsemann (1967). Except for the ist antenna and<tei:lb/>2nd maxilla the mouthparts of the present female are identical to those of the male.<tei:lb/>The ist lobe of the 2nd maxilla bears a single seta in both the present female and<tei:lb/>that of Tanaka &amp; Omori ; this is not shown by Grice &amp; Hulsemann but it is easily<tei:lb/>damaged when the appendage is dissected off the body. The endopod of the 2nd<tei:lb/>maxilla in the present specimen has more setae than either the male or Tanaka &amp;<tei:lb/>Omori's female. The proportions of the rami in the 2nd antenna are similar in the<tei:lb/>present female and the male. The endopodite of the ist leg has three segments in<tei:lb/>the male but only two in both females ; the remaining swimming legs of the male<tei:lb/>are not described in detail by Grice &amp; Hulsemann.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Except for normal sexual differences the only real difference between the females<tei:lb/>and the male is in the segmentation of the ist leg. Intraspecific variation occurs<tei:lb/>in Euaugaptilus, however, both in the setation of the mouthparts and in the seg-<tei:lb/>mentation of the ist leg (Matthews, 1972). Grice &amp; Hulsemann (1967) and Matthews<tei:lb/>(1972) were unable to refer the male to a known species but pointed out similarities<tei:lb/>with E. rigidus (Sars, 1907). The true male of E. rigidus is described below (p.<tei:lb/>357), and the agreement between the present female and the male E. sp. 3 is so good<tei:lb/>that I have no doubt that they are conspecific.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>352</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>

         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 353</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus latifrons (Sars, 1907)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 2 females from 2 Nii3H hauls made at 800-475 m depth<tei:lb/>off Fuerteventura (28N I4W) on 26 November 1965. 3 females from 2 RMT i<tei:lb/>hauls made at 700-505 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 14 and 15 Novem-<tei:lb/>ber 1969.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The present females (Fig. 261- q) agree generally with the descrip-<tei:lb/>tions of Sars (1924, 1925), Sewell (1932) and, particularly, Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974).<tei:lb/>There is tremendous variation in the number of setae on the 2nd maxilla in this<tei:lb/>species. Tanaka &amp; Omori discussed this in relation to their specimen and those of<tei:lb/>Sars, Sewell and Vervoort (1965). The present females have the following numbers<tei:lb/>of setae on the various lobes of the 2nd maxilla :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Station no. of Lobes of 2nd maxilla</tei:p>
         <tei:p>specimen 123456 Endopod</tei:p>

         <tei:p>no. 1 6 (2nd specimen) 10122 14</tei:p>
         <tei:p>no. I7\ . 101235 J 2 (right side)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>' &gt;same specimen j. * . , . '</tei:p>

         <tei:p>In the 2nd maxilla of some of these females lobe 6 and the endopod cannot be<tei:lb/>distinguished, and in one specimen there is some variation between the left and right<tei:lb/>side. The present specimens measure 4-96-6-72 mm with a mean of 5-63 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus maxillaris Sars, 1920</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 3 females from 3 Nii3H hauls made at 960-550 m depth<tei:lb/>off Fuerteventura (28N I4W), between 24 and 28 November 1965. 3 females and<tei:lb/>2 males from 3 RMT i hauls made at 785-610 m depth in a position i8N 25W,<tei:lb/>between 13 and 14 November 1969. 5 females and the males are deposited at the<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 664-670.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 27a-g) : Body length 3-27-5-76 mm with a mean<tei:lb/>of 5-11 mm (6 specimens). The cephalothorax is long and narrow and just over<tei:lb/>3-5 times as long as the 3-segmented abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment<tei:lb/>are separate. The forehead and hind margin of the cephalothorax are rounded.<tei:lb/>The genital segment is 1-8 times as long as the combined length of the two subsequent<tei:lb/>segments. The ist antenna has 25 segments and exceeds the body length by<tei:lb/>4-5 segments. Except for the ist maxilla the remaining mouthparts are as figured<tei:lb/>by Sars (1924). The distal setae of the 2nd maxilla and maxilliped have very small<tei:lb/>'buttons'. The ist maxilla (Fig. 276, f) differs from the descriptions of Sars (1924,<tei:lb/>1925) and Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974) in the development of the endopodite. Both<tei:lb/>Sars' and Tanaka &amp; Omori's specimens had a single endopodite segment with five<tei:lb/>setae. One of the females illustrated here has two endopodite segments bearing</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>354</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 27. a-g, Euaugaptilus maxillaris ?. a, body, dorsal ; b, rostrum, ventral ; c,<tei:lb/>mandibular palp ; d, mandible blade ; e, ist maxilla ; f, ist maxilla, small specimen ;<tei:lb/>g, 2nd maxilla, h-i, Euaugaptilis maxillaris $. h, body, dorsal ; i, 5th legs. Bar<tei:lb/>scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>three and four setae (Fig. 276). Both the segmentation and setation of this endo-<tei:lb/>podite are subject to variation however, since two other specimens have only a<tei:lb/>single segment with six and seven setae respectively. The endopodite of the ist<tei:lb/>maxilla of the smallest female (3-27 mm, Fig. 27f) agrees with Sars' account but the<tei:lb/>2nd and 3rd endites have two and one setae respectively - the converse of the<tei:lb/>arrangement in both previous accounts and in the other specimens here. The<tei:lb/>swimming legs are as described by Sars.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male (Fig. 27!!, i) : Body length 5-12 mm (both specimens). The cephalothorax<tei:lb/>is 3-5 times as long as the 5-segmented abdomen. The head and ist thoracic seg-<tei:lb/>ment are separate ; thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused. In dorsal view the fore-<tei:lb/>head protrudes more than in the female ; the rostrum has two fairly long filaments.<tei:lb/>The furcal rami are twice as long as wide. The left ist antenna is presumably</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 355</tei:p>
         <tei:p>geniculate but is broken in both specimens ; the right ist antenna has 25 segments<tei:lb/>and exceeds the body length by five segments. The remaining mouthparts are<tei:lb/>identical to those of the present females. Both specimens have only a single endo-<tei:lb/>podite segment in the ist maxilla, carrying seven and eight setae respectively ;<tei:lb/>otherwise this appendage is as shown in Fig. 276.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The swimming legs are the same as in the female. The 5th pair of legs is slightly<tei:lb/>asymmetrical. The external exopodite spines on the left leg are missing in the<tei:lb/>illustrated specimen but present in the other. The 2nd basipodite segment of both<tei:lb/>legs has a small patch of spines. The endopodites are 3-segmented on both sides<tei:lb/>and are omitted here for clarity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The female of E. maxillaris has only been described and figured by<tei:lb/>Sars (1924, 1925) and by Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974). The male has hitherto been<tei:lb/>unknown. The present female specimens agree with these descriptions and I have<tei:lb/>no doubt that they are conspecific. The variation in structure of the ist maxilla<tei:lb/>accords with the intraspecific variations noted in Euaugaptilm by Matthews (1972)<tei:lb/>and by Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974). Similar differences are also present in several of<tei:lb/>the species described here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus ? longicirrhus (Sars, 1905)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : i female taken in an NiiaH fished at 800-680 m depth<tei:lb/>off Fuerteventura (28N I4W) on 26 November 1965. 3 females and I male from<tei:lb/>2 RMT i hauls made at 500-410 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between 22 and<tei:lb/>24 November 1969. 3 females and the male are deposited at the British Museum<tei:lb/>(Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 671-674.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 28a-c) : Body length 4-18-4-56 mm with a mean<tei:lb/>of 4-31 mm (4 specimens). The general appearance of the body is as shown by Sars<tei:lb/>(1924). The rostral filaments are very long. Except for the 2nd maxilla the<tei:lb/>mouthparts of the present females are the same as those of the male, and fit Sewell's<tei:lb/>(1947) description better than Sars'. The mandibular palp is very reduced with the<tei:lb/>exopod having four and the endopod two setae ; the blade has two more teeth than<tei:lb/>either Sars' or Sewell's specimens. The ist maxilla is reduced and agrees with<tei:lb/>Sewell's description. The 2nd maxilla has 3 (2 long and i spike), i, 2, 3, 2 and 3<tei:lb/>setae on lobes 1-6 respectively, whereas Sars' specimen had , i, 2, 3, 3, 3 setae<tei:lb/>and Sewell's 2, ,2,3,2 and 3. The legs all have 3-segmented exopods and endo-<tei:lb/>pods - the ist pair thereby agreeing with Sewell's account rather than Sars'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male (Fig. 28d-h) : Body length 3-42 mm. The cephalothorax is similar in<tei:lb/>shape to the female but has slightly more conspicuous shoulders. It is 3-7 times as<tei:lb/>long as the 5-segmented abdomen. Thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused and the<tei:lb/>hind margin of the cephalothorax is rounded. The rostral filaments are very long.<tei:lb/>The left ist antenna reaches to the end of the abdomen ; it is geniculate and has 21<tei:lb/>segments. The right ist antenna is broken. The mouthparts are as shown and are<tei:lb/>identical to the female except that the ist lobe of the 2nd maxilla has only one seta.<tei:lb/>The swimming legs are the same as in the female. The 5th pair of legs are slightly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>356</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>n</tei:p>

         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS 357</tei:p>
         <tei:p>asymmetrical. The 2nd exopodite segment of the right leg has a small haired lobe ;<tei:lb/>the 2nd basipodite segment of both legs has a patch of raised spots on its internal<tei:lb/>edge. The endopods of both legs are 3-segmented.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. E. longicirrhus was described by Sars (1924, 1925) from an adult<tei:lb/>female. The only other description is by Sewell (1947) who attributed a stage V<tei:lb/>female copepodite to this species. Matthews (1972) agreed with Sewell and kindly<tei:lb/>identified the present female taken off Fuerteventura (Roe, 1972^). The appendages<tei:lb/>of Sewell's specimen differ from those of Sars' in several respects - the exopodite of<tei:lb/>the ist pair of legs has three segments not two, and the mandibular palp and ist<tei:lb/>and 2nd maxillae differ in details of their setation. The present specimens show<tei:lb/>almost complete agreement with Sewell's account and if his copepodite is E. longi-<tei:lb/>cirrhus then the specimens described here are also this species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus rigidus (Sars, 1907)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 2 females from 2 NiisH hauls made at 590-450 m depth<tei:lb/>off Fuerteventura (28N I4W), between 15 and 26 November 1965. i female and<tei:lb/>i male from 2 RMT i hauls made at 785-300 m depth in a position i8N 25 W,<tei:lb/>between 13 and 14 November 1969. The male is deposited at the British Museum<tei:lb/>(Natural History), reg. no. 1974 : 675.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male (Fig. 28i-o) : Body length c. 4-3 mm but as the cephalotho-<tei:lb/>rax was fractured accurate measurements are impossible. The general appearance<tei:lb/>of the body, especially the shape of the head and hind margin of the cephalo-<tei:lb/>thorax, are as for the female. The head and ist thoracic segment are separate but<tei:lb/>thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused. The rostrum has two filaments of medium<tei:lb/>length. The abdomen has five segments ; the furcal rami are about 1-5 times as<tei:lb/>long as wide. The ist antenna are broken off on both sides. Except for the 2nd<tei:lb/>maxilla the other mouthparts are identical to the female described by Sars (1924,<tei:lb/>1925). On the present specimen the first six lobes of the 2nd maxilla bear 2, i, i,<tei:lb/>3, 2 and i setae respectively ; whereas Sars' female had i, i, i, 2, 2 and i setae on<tei:lb/>these lobes. Slight variation in the setation of this appendage occurs, however,<tei:lb/>since the female described by Tanaka (1964) had 2, i, i, 3, 2 and 2 setae and the<tei:lb/>present females have 2, i, i, 3, 2, i (two specimens) and 2, , i, 3, 2, i setae respect-<tei:lb/>ively. The first four pairs of legs are identical to the female. The 5th pair of legs<tei:lb/>is slightly asymmetrical. The 2nd exopodal segment of the right leg has a pointed<tei:lb/>lobe on its inner margin ; the outer spine of this segment is missing and apparently<tei:lb/>broken off. The 2nd basipodite segment of both legs has a small corrugated patch.<tei:lb/>The endopodite on both sides has three segments and is omitted for clarity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The agreement between this specimen and the female is so good that<tei:lb/>I have no doubt that they are conspecific. The slight variation in setation of the<tei:lb/>2nd maxilla is not surprising since Matthews (1972) found a considerable degree of<tei:lb/>intraspecific variation in this genus. Vervoort (1965) reported a damaged male of<tei:lb/>this species, measuring 4-30 mm, but it has hitherto been undescribed. The male<tei:lb/>E. sp. 3 of Grice &amp; Hulsemann (1967) has been discussed earlier (p. 351).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>358 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus mixtus (Sars, 1907)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus propinquus Sars, 1920 : 17 ; 1924 : pi. 102 ; 1925 : 297 ; Rose, 1933 : 221, 230,<tei:lb/>fig. 283 ; Vives, 1970 : 554-555 ; 1972 : 221-222 ; Matthews, 1972 : 39 ; Tanaka &amp; Omori,<tei:lb/>1974 : J 93 J 97&gt; J 99 2OO &gt; 248-250, figs 3h, 26.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 2 females in 2 Nii3H hauls made at 960-750 m depth<tei:lb/>off Fuerteventura (28N I4W), between 25 and 28 November 1965. 5 females<tei:lb/>taken in 5 RMT I hauls made at 900-410 m depth in a position i8N 25W, between<tei:lb/>12 and 16 November 1969. 6 females are deposited at the British Museum (Natural<tei:lb/>History), reg. no. 1974 : 676-681.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female (Fig. 2911-0) : Body length 3-50-3-80 mm with a mean<tei:lb/>of 3-65 mm (7 specimens). The general appearance of the body is as shown by Sars<tei:lb/>(1924), Hulsemann (1967) and Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974). The cephalothorax is<tei:lb/>2-6 times as long as the 3-segmented abdomen. The head and ist thoracic segment<tei:lb/>are separate ; thoracic segments 4 and 5 are fused. The forehead is rounded and<tei:lb/>the rostrum has two filaments of medium length. The hind margin of the cephalo-<tei:lb/>thorax is rounded in dorsal view but slightly angular when seen laterally. The<tei:lb/>genital segment is about 1-5 times as long as the combined length of the two subse-<tei:lb/>quent segments. The furcal rami are twice as long as wide. The ist antenna has<tei:lb/>25 segments and exceeds the body length by 2-3 segments. The remaining mouth-<tei:lb/>parts are as shown but there is slight variation in the setation of both the 2nd antenna<tei:lb/>and ist maxilla, and in the number of mandibular teeth. The 2nd antenna was<tei:lb/>examined in three specimens, two of which had nine large setae on the endopodite<tei:lb/>and the 3rd (Fig. 29]) had eight. The ist outer lobe of the ist maxilla has six large<tei:lb/>and one small setae in three specimens, six large in one, five ? large in one, and five<tei:lb/>large and one small in another (Fig. 29m). The mandibular teeth are in groups of<tei:lb/>2, 2 and 3 in four specimens (Fig. 29!), but in two of these four examples the second<tei:lb/>tooth of the middle group is minute and could easily be overlooked ; a further speci-<tei:lb/>men has 2, 2 and 2 teeth, and another 2, i and 3. The distal setae of the 2nd maxilla<tei:lb/>and maxilliped have well-developed 'buttons'. The legs agree with previous<tei:lb/>descriptions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. E. mixtus was described briefly by Sars in 1907 from Trincesse Alice'<tei:lb/>station 1794. It does not, however, appear in the list of copepods taken at this<tei:lb/>station in Sars (1925). The only other record of this species is by Lysholm &amp;<tei:lb/>Nordgaard (1945). This specimen was probably identified by Sars and was re-<tei:lb/>described by Hulsemann (1967). E. propinquus was described briefly by Sars in<tei:lb/>1920 and more fully in 1924 and 1925. It was recorded by Vives (1970, 1972) and a<tei:lb/>further description has recently been given by Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974). Sars listed<tei:lb/>his specimens as coming from Trincesse Alice' stations 1781, 2738 and 3021. I have<tei:lb/>borrowed a female specimen of E, propinquus from the Oceanographic Museum,<tei:lb/>Monaco, which was caught at station 1768 in 1904. This specimen is not mentioned<tei:lb/>by Sars and it is not on his list of species taken at this station.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hulsemann (1967) pointed out the similarity between E. mixtus and E. propinquus<tei:lb/>and said that they could be distinguished by (a) a slightly different shaped forehead,<tei:lb/>(b) the mandibular tooth arrangement is 2, i and 3 in E. mixtus and 2, 2 and 2 in</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW AND RARE CALANOID COPEPODS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>359</tei:p>
         <tei:p>n</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 29. a-g, Euaugaptilus hyperboreus &lt;J. a, 2nd antenna ; b, mandibular palp ; c,<tei:lb/>mandible blade ; d, ist maxilla ; e, 2nd maxilla ; f, maxilliped ; g, 5th legs, h-o,<tei:lb/>Euaugaptilus mixtus ?. h, body, dorsal ; i, forehead and rostrum, lateral ; j, and<tei:lb/>antenna (different specimen) ; k, mandibular palp ; 1, mandible blade ; m, ist maxilla ;<tei:lb/>n, 2nd maxilla ; o, maxilliped (different specimen). Bar scale o-i mm unless indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>360 H. S. J. ROE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. propinquus, and (c) the ist maxilla of E. mixtus has one seta on the 2nd basipodite<tei:lb/>and six large setae on the exopodite, whereas these segments in E. propinquus have<tei:lb/>two setae and five large and one small seta respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female described by Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974) is identical to the present<tei:lb/>'Discovery' specimens. These latter females are intermediate between E. mixtus<tei:lb/>and E. propinquus (Roe, 1972^). In all of them the setation of the ist maxilla<tei:lb/>agrees with that of E. mixtus but the arrangement of the mandibular teeth varies.<tei:lb/>One specimen has the pattern described by Hulsemann for E. mixtus, one that<tei:lb/>described by Sars for E. propinquus, and four have a varying and intermediate<tei:lb/>arrangement. Without dissection it is difficult to ascertain the setation of the ist<tei:lb/>maxilla of the 'Princesse Alice' specimen. However, it definitely has five large and<tei:lb/>one small seta on the exopod but I could see only one seta on the 2nd basipodite.<tei:lb/>The mandibular tooth arrangement of this specimen differs from any described<tei:lb/>above and is I, I and 4. The cephalothorax of this specimen is distorted and the<tei:lb/>shape of the forehead cannot be accurately determined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The differences between these two species are very slight. The presence of an<tei:lb/>additional seta on the ist maxilla and one of a different size seem well within the<tei:lb/>range of intraspecific variation seen in several Euaugaptilus spp. (for example, see<tei:lb/>P- 355)- The shape of the forehead may well be variable and the mandibular tooth<tei:lb/>pattern certainly is. Furthermore, it is clear that the detailed structure of Sars'<tei:lb/>material was not uniform. I believe that there is no essential difference between<tei:lb/>E. mixtus and E. propinquus and that they are synonymous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus hyperboreus Brodsky, 1950</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euaugaptilus hyperboreus ? ; Roe, 19720 : 299, 311 ; 19720" : 1035.<tei:lb/>E. elongatus ; Roe, 19720 : 299, 306, 311.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED : 2 females and i male taken in 3 Nii3H hauls made at<tei:lb/>950-600 m depth off Fuerteventura (28N I4W), between 26 and 28 November<tei:lb/>1965. 2 females taken in 2RMT I hauls made at 1220-800 m depth and I female<tei:lb/>in an RMT 8 fished at 1020-910 m in a position i8N 25W, between 14 and 18<tei:lb/>November 1969.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Tanaka &amp; Omori (1974) have recently clarified the differences<tei:lb/>between this species and Euaugaptilus elongatus (Sars, 1905). In the course of the<tei:lb/>present work I borrowed a male and a female specimen of E. elongatus from the<tei:lb/>Oceanographic Museum, Monaco, both of which were taken at 'Princesse Alice'<tei:lb/>station 1781 on 21 August 1904. These specimens and the present 'Discovery'<tei:lb/>material confirm the differences in the setation of the ist and 2nd maxillae observed<tei:lb/>by Tanaka &amp; Omori. These differences are shown in Table I.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Slight variation occurs in the setation of the ist maxilla endopodite of E. hyper-<tei:lb/>boreus, but none of the present specimens, nor those examined by Tanaka &amp; Omori,<tei:lb/>have three setae on this lobe. Some differences are also present in the setation of<tei:lb/>the 2nd basipodite of the ist maxilla, where the 'Discovery' male (Fig. 2ga-g) has</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
